title: CORL: Reinforcement Learning of MILP Policies Solved via Branch and Bound
summary: Combinatorial sequential decision making problems are typically modeled as mixed integer linear programs (MILPs) and solved via branch and bound (B&B) algorithms. The inherent difficulty of modeling MILPs that accurately represent stochastic real world problems leads to suboptimal performance in the real world. Recently, machine learning methods have been applied to build MILP models for decision quality rather than how accurately they model the real world problem. However, these approaches typically rely on supervised learning, assume access to true optimal decisions, and use surrogates for the MILP gradients. In this work, we introduce a proof of concept CORL framework that end to end fine tunes an MILP scheme using reinforcement learning (RL) on real world data to maximize its operational performance. We enable this by casting an MILP solved by B&B as a differentiable stochastic policy compatible with RL. We validate the CORL method in a simple illustrative combinatorial sequential decision making example.

AI.tldr: They propose CORL, an RL-based framework to directly fine-tune how a MILP with branch-and-bound is used, optimizing real-world decision performance instead of model fidelity.
AI.motivation: Classical MILPs for combinatorial sequential decision making are hard to specify accurately for stochastic real-world systems, so even exact optimization can deliver poor real-world performance. Recent ML methods optimize MILP formulations for decision quality, but they usually need labeled optimal decisions and gradient surrogates, which limits applicability. There is a need for an approach that directly optimizes the operational performance of an MILP-based decision scheme on real data without requiring ground-truth optimal solutions.
AI.method: They reinterpret an MILP solved via branch-and-bound as a differentiable stochastic policy, which makes it amenable to standard reinforcement learning algorithms. Using this view, they construct CORL, an end-to-end RL framework that adjusts or fine-tunes elements of the MILP formulation/solution process to maximize a real-world reward signal derived from data, bypassing supervised learning and surrogate gradients.
AI.result: Using a simple illustrative combinatorial sequential decision-making task, they show that CORL can successfully be trained and that it improves the operational performance of the MILP-based decision process, demonstrating the feasibility of treating B&B-solved MILPs as RL policies.
AI.conclusion: Casting MILPs with branch-and-bound as differentiable stochastic policies makes it possible to fine-tune them with reinforcement learning directly on real-world performance metrics. The CORL proof-of-concept indicates that this approach is viable and potentially superior to supervised or purely model-based MILP design for complex, stochastic decision problems.

title: Deep Learning--Accelerated Multi-Start Large Neighborhood Search for Real-time Freight Bundling
summary: Online Freight Exchange Systems (OFEX) play a crucial role in modern freight logistics by facilitating real-time matching between shippers and carrier. However, efficient combinatorial bundling of transporation jobs remains a bottleneck. We model the OFEX combinatorial bundling problem as a multi-commodity one-to-one pickup-and-delivery selective traveling salesperson problem (m1-PDSTSP), which optimizes revenue-driven freight bundling under capacity, precedence, and route-length constraints. The key challenge is to couple combinatorial bundle selection with pickup-and-delivery routing under sub-second latency. We propose a learning--accelerated hybrid search pipeline that pairs a Transformer Neural Network-based constructive policy with an innovative Multi-Start Large Neighborhood Search (MSLNS) metaheuristic within a rolling-horizon scheme in which the platform repeatedly freezes the current marketplace into a static snapshot and solves it under a short time budget. This pairing leverages the low-latency, high-quality inference of the learning-based constructor alongside the robustness of improvement search; the multi-start design and plausible seeds help LNS to explore the solution space more efficiently. Across benchmarks, our method outperforms state-of-the-art neural combinatorial optimization and metaheuristic baselines in solution quality with comparable time, achieving an optimality gap of less than 2\% in total revenue relative to the best available exact baseline method. To our knowledge, this is the first work to establish that a Deep Neural Network-based constructor can reliably provide high-quality seeds for (multi-start) improvement heuristics, with applicability beyond the \textit{m1-PDSTSP} to a broad class of selective traveling salesperson problems and pickup and delivery problems.

AI.tldr: Paper proposes a learning-accelerated hybrid search method for efficient combinatorial bundling of freight jobs in Online Freight Exchange Systems, achieving near-optimal revenue within sub-second latency.
AI.motivation: Online Freight Exchange Systems must quickly and efficiently bundle transportation jobs into profitable routes, but existing methods struggle to couple combinatorial selection with pickup-and-delivery routing under strict time limits. There is a need for methods that are both high-quality and fast enough for real-time decision-making.
AI.method: Model the problem as a multi-commodity one-to-one pickup-and-delivery selective TSP (m1-PDSTSP). Use a rolling-horizon framework where the marketplace is repeatedly frozen into static snapshots. For each snapshot, apply a learning-accelerated hybrid pipeline: a Transformer-based constructive policy first generates high-quality initial solutions (seeds), which are then improved by a Multi-Start Large Neighborhood Search (MSLNS) metaheuristic. The multi-start and seeded design let LNS explore the solution space more effectively within tight time budgets.
AI.result: Across benchmark instances, the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art neural combinatorial optimization and classical metaheuristic baselines in solution quality while keeping comparable computation time, achieving less than 2% optimality gap in total revenue relative to the best available exact method.
AI.conclusion: A deep neural network-based constructor can reliably provide high-quality seeds for multi-start improvement heuristics in complex routing and bundling problems. The approach is effective for the m1-PDSTSP and is expected to generalize to a broad class of selective TSP and pickup-and-delivery problems, offering a practical solution for real-time freight bundling in OFEX platforms.

title: FutureWeaver: Planning Test-Time Compute for Multi-Agent Systems with Modularized Collaboration
summary: Scaling test-time computation improves large language model performance without additional training. Recent work demonstrates that techniques such as repeated sampling, self-verification, and self-reflection can significantly enhance task success by allocating more inference-time compute. However, applying these techniques across multiple agents in a multi-agent system is difficult: there does not exist principled mechanisms to allocate compute to foster collaboration among agents, to extend test-time scaling to collaborative interactions, or to distribute compute across agents under explicit budget constraints. To address this gap, we propose FutureWeaver, a framework for planning and optimizing test-time compute allocation in multi-agent systems under fixed budgets. FutureWeaver introduces modularized collaboration, formalized as callable functions that encapsulate reusable multi-agent workflows. These modules are automatically derived through self-play reflection by abstracting recurring interaction patterns from past trajectories. Building on these modules, FutureWeaver employs a dual-level planning architecture that optimizes compute allocation by reasoning over the current task state while also speculating on future steps. Experiments on complex agent benchmarks demonstrate that FutureWeaver consistently outperforms baselines across diverse budget settings, validating its effectiveness for multi-agent collaboration in inference-time optimization.

AI.tldr: FutureWeaver is a framework that optimally allocates test-time compute across multiple collaborating LLM agents under a fixed budget, using learned modular interaction patterns and a dual-level planner to significantly improve performance on complex tasks.
AI.motivation: Existing test-time scaling techniques (e.g., repeated sampling, self-verification, self-reflection) improve single-agent LLM performance by spending more compute at inference, but they lack principled ways to extend to multi-agent settings. Specifically, there is no structured method to: (1) decide how much compute each agent should use, (2) foster effective collaboration with reusable workflows, or (3) respect global budget constraints when distributing compute. This limits the effectiveness and practicality of multi-agent systems in complex tasks where planning, coordination, and constrained resources matter.
AI.method: The paper proposes FutureWeaver, a framework for multi-agent LLM systems that plans and optimizes test-time compute allocation under fixed budgets. It introduces: (1) modularized collaboration primitives, represented as callable functions that encode reusable multi-agent interaction workflows; (2) an automatic module discovery process using self-play reflection, which scans prior trajectories to abstract recurrent, successful interaction patterns into these modules; and (3) a dual-level planning architecture that jointly reasons about immediate task needs and speculative future steps to decide where and when to invoke modules, and how much compute to allocate to each agent and interaction, while obeying an overall compute budget.
AI.result: On complex multi-agent benchmarks, FutureWeaver is empirically shown to consistently outperform baseline methods that either do not use structured collaboration or do not optimize compute allocation. The gains hold across a wide range of compute budgets, indicating that the framework not only improves raw performance but also makes better use of limited inference-time resources. Ablations likely show contributions from modularization, self-play-derived modules, and the dual-level planner.
AI.conclusion: FutureWeaver demonstrates that principled planning of inference-time compute in multi-agent LLM systems—via reusable collaboration modules and dual-level budget-aware planning—can substantially enhance performance under fixed compute budgets. This suggests that future progress in multi-agent AI may rely as much on smarter orchestration and compute allocation at test time as on larger models or additional training, and that modular, learned collaboration patterns are a promising direction for scalable multi-agent coordination.

title: A-LAMP: Agentic LLM-Based Framework for Automated MDP Modeling and Policy Generation
comment: NeurIPS 2025 Workshop: Multi-Turn Interactions in Large Language Models. 26 pages, 8 figures
summary: Applying reinforcement learning (RL) to real-world tasks requires converting informal descriptions into a formal Markov decision process (MDP), implementing an executable environment, and training a policy agent. Automating this process is challenging due to modeling errors, fragile code, and misaligned objectives, which often impede policy training. We introduce an agentic large language model (LLM)-based framework for automated MDP modeling and policy generation (A-LAMP), that automatically translates free-form natural language task descriptions into an MDP formulation and trained policy. The framework decomposes modeling, coding, and training into verifiable stages, ensuring semantic alignment throughout the pipeline. Across both classic control and custom RL domains, A-LAMP consistently achieves higher policy generation capability than a single state-of-the-art LLM model. Notably, even its lightweight variant, which is built on smaller language models, approaches the performance of much larger models. Failure analysis reveals why these improvements occur. In addition, a case study also demonstrates that A-LAMP generates environments and policies that preserve the task's optimality, confirming its correctness and reliability.

AI.tldr: The paper presents A-LAMP, an agentic LLM-based framework that automatically converts natural language task descriptions into MDPs and trains RL policies, outperforming single LLM baselines and remaining strong even in a lightweight variant.
AI.motivation: Using RL in real-world problems requires experts to manually translate informal task descriptions into formal MDPs, code environments, and train policies. This process is error-prone, fragile, and often misaligned with the intended task, making RL hard to deploy at scale. Automating this end-to-end pipeline with language models is desirable but challenging due to modeling errors and objective misalignment.
AI.method: The authors design A-LAMP, an agentic framework built around large language models that orchestrates multiple stages: (1) translating free-form natural language task descriptions into a formal MDP specification, (2) generating executable environment code from that specification, and (3) producing and training an RL policy. The pipeline is decomposed into verifiable stages to check semantic alignment and correctness at each step. The framework includes a lightweight variant that uses smaller LLMs and still follows the same multi-stage process.
AI.result: Across a range of classic control benchmarks and custom RL domains, A-LAMP yields better policy generation performance than a single state-of-the-art LLM used in a non-agentic way. The lightweight version, despite being based on smaller models, still approaches the performance of larger models. A failure analysis identifies why the multi-stage, verifiable pipeline improves robustness and alignment.
AI.conclusion: A-LAMP demonstrates that an agentic, multi-stage LLM framework can reliably automate the conversion of natural language task descriptions into MDPs, executable environments, and trained RL policies. The approach improves policy quality, maintains task optimality, and offers a scalable path toward more automatic, trustworthy application of RL to real-world tasks, even with smaller language models.

title: ASR Under the Stethoscope: Evaluating Biases in Clinical Speech Recognition across Indian Languages
summary: Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) is increasingly used to document clinical encounters, yet its reliability in multilingual and demographically diverse Indian healthcare contexts remains largely unknown. In this study, we conduct the first systematic audit of ASR performance on real world clinical interview data spanning Kannada, Hindi, and Indian English, comparing leading models including Indic Whisper, Whisper, Sarvam, Google speech to text, Gemma3n, Omnilingual, Vaani, and Gemini. We evaluate transcription accuracy across languages, speakers, and demographic subgroups, with a particular focus on error patterns affecting patients vs. clinicians and gender based or intersectional disparities. Our results reveal substantial variability across models and languages, with some systems performing competitively on Indian English but failing on code mixed or vernacular speech. We also uncover systematic performance gaps tied to speaker role and gender, raising concerns about equitable deployment in clinical settings. By providing a comprehensive multilingual benchmark and fairness analysis, our work highlights the need for culturally and demographically inclusive ASR development for healthcare ecosystem in India.

AI.tldr: The paper audits how well various automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems work on real-world Indian clinical interviews in Kannada, Hindi, and Indian English, with an emphasis on fairness across roles and demographics.
AI.motivation: ASR is increasingly used to document clinical encounters, but its accuracy and fairness in multilingual, demographically diverse Indian healthcare settings is unclear, especially for vernacular, code-mixed speech. There is a risk that unreliable or biased ASR could harm documentation quality and exacerbate inequities in care.
AI.method: The authors perform a systematic audit of multiple state-of-the-art ASR models (Indic Whisper, Whisper, Sarvam, Google Speech-to-Text, Gemma3n, Omnilingual, Vaani, Gemini) on real-world clinical interviews in Kannada, Hindi, and Indian English. They evaluate transcription accuracy across languages, speakers, and demographic subgroups, and analyze error patterns particularly by speaker role (patient vs. clinician), gender, and intersectional combinations.
AI.result: They find large variability in performance across models and languages: some systems work reasonably well on Indian English but perform poorly on vernacular or code-mixed speech. They also identify systematic performance gaps associated with speaker role and gender, indicating unequal ASR quality for different groups in clinical settings.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a multilingual benchmark and fairness analysis for clinical ASR in India, demonstrating that current systems are not uniformly reliable or fair across languages and demographics. It underscores the need for culturally and demographically inclusive ASR design and evaluation before deploying such systems in Indian healthcare environments.

title: TriFlow: A Progressive Multi-Agent Framework for Intelligent Trip Planning
summary: Real-world trip planning requires transforming open-ended user requests into executable itineraries under strict spatial, temporal, and budgetary constraints while aligning with user preferences. Existing LLM-based agents struggle with constraint satisfaction, tool coordination, and efficiency, often producing infeasible or costly plans. To address these limitations, we present TriFlow, a progressive multi-agent framework that unifies structured reasoning and language-based flexibility through a three-stage pipeline of retrieval, planning, and governance. By this design, TriFlow progressively narrows the search space, assembles constraint-consistent itineraries via rule-LLM collaboration, and performs bounded iterative refinement to ensure global feasibility and personalisation. Evaluations on TravelPlanner and TripTailor benchmarks demonstrated state-of-the-art results, achieving 91.1% and 97% final pass rates, respectively, with over 10x runtime efficiency improvement compared to current SOTA.

AI.tldr: TriFlow is a multi-agent framework that turns open-ended travel requests into feasible, personalized itineraries under strict constraints, achieving SOTA accuracy and >10x efficiency over prior LLM agents.
AI.motivation: Real-world trip planning from free-form user requests is hard because itineraries must satisfy spatial, temporal, and budget constraints while reflecting user preferences. Existing LLM-based planning agents often violate constraints, use tools inefficiently, and generate infeasible or overly expensive plans. There is a need for a system that combines LLM flexibility with structured constraint handling to reliably produce executable itineraries.
AI.method: TriFlow introduces a progressive three-stage multi-agent pipeline: (1) Retrieval: gather relevant candidate activities and options from tools or databases given the user’s request; (2) Planning: use collaboration between rule-based components and LLMs to assemble itineraries that respect constraints, incrementally narrowing the search space; (3) Governance: apply bounded iterative refinement via a governance agent that checks global feasibility (constraints, cost, timing) and personalisation and adjusts the plan as needed. This framework explicitly coordinates multiple agents and tools to maintain constraint consistency and efficiency.
AI.result: On two travel-planning benchmarks, TravelPlanner and TripTailor, TriFlow achieves state-of-the-art performance: 91.1% and 97% final pass rates, respectively, indicating a high fraction of fully feasible and acceptable plans. It also delivers more than 10x runtime efficiency improvement compared to prior state-of-the-art LLM-based trip planning systems.
AI.conclusion: A progressively structured multi-agent framework that combines rule-based constraint reasoning with LLM flexibility can substantially improve the feasibility, personalization, and computational efficiency of LLM-based trip planning. TriFlow’s retrieval–planning–governance pipeline yields state-of-the-art performance on standard benchmarks, suggesting that similar architectures may benefit other constrained planning domains beyond travel.

title: Benchmarking Automatic Speech Recognition Models for African Languages
comment: 19 pages, 8 figures, Deep Learning Indiba, Proceedings of Machine Learning Research
summary: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) for African languages remains constrained by limited labeled data and the lack of systematic guidance on model selection, data scaling, and decoding strategies. Large pre-trained systems such as Whisper, XLS-R, MMS, and W2v-BERT have expanded access to ASR technology, but their comparative behavior in African low-resource contexts has not been studied in a unified and systematic way. In this work, we benchmark four state-of-the-art ASR models across 13 African languages, fine-tuning them on progressively larger subsets of transcribed data ranging from 1 to 400 hours. Beyond reporting error rates, we provide new insights into why models behave differently under varying conditions. We show that MMS and W2v-BERT are more data efficient in very low-resource regimes, XLS-R scales more effectively as additional data becomes available, and Whisper demonstrates advantages in mid-resource conditions. We also analyze where external language model decoding yields improvements and identify cases where it plateaus or introduces additional errors, depending on the alignment between acoustic and text resources. By highlighting the interaction between pre-training coverage, model architecture, dataset domain, and resource availability, this study offers practical and insights into the design of ASR systems for underrepresented languages.

AI.tldr: The paper benchmarks four major pre-trained ASR models on 13 African languages across data scales from 1–400 hours, revealing how their performance and data efficiency differ by resource level and decoding setup, and deriving practical guidance for low-resource ASR design.
AI.motivation: ASR for African languages is hindered by scarce labeled data and the absence of systematic guidance on which pre-trained model, data regime, and decoding strategy to use. Although large multilingual ASR models like Whisper, XLS-R, MMS, and W2v-BERT exist, their comparative behavior in low-resource African settings has not been studied in a unified way. The authors want to fill this gap to help practitioners make informed choices when building ASR for underrepresented languages.
AI.method: The authors benchmark four state-of-the-art pre-trained ASR systems—Whisper, XLS-R, MMS, and W2v-BERT—on 13 African languages. They fine-tune each model on progressively larger subsets of transcribed speech, ranging approximately from 1 hour up to 400 hours per language or dataset. They evaluate word/character error rates and go beyond raw scores by analyzing how model performance scales with data, how pre-training coverage and architecture affect gains, and how external language model (LM) decoding impacts results. They specifically examine cases where LM fusion helps, saturates, or harms performance depending on alignment between the acoustic training data and text resources used for the LM.
AI.result: The experiments show distinct performance regimes across models: MMS and W2v-BERT are more data efficient and perform better in extremely low-resource settings (few hours of labeled data); XLS-R benefits more from additional labeled data and scales best as more transcribed speech becomes available; Whisper provides competitive or superior performance in mid-resource regimes. The analysis of LM decoding shows that external LMs can substantially improve recognition in some cases, but their benefit plateaus or can even degrade performance when the LM text data is poorly aligned with the acoustic domain or language variety of the speech data.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that there is no single best ASR model for all African low-resource conditions; instead, the optimal choice depends on the available labeled data, pre-training coverage, and domain alignment. MMS and W2v-BERT should be preferred in very low-resource scenarios, XLS-R is a strong option when larger labeled datasets are attainable, and Whisper is attractive for intermediate-resource conditions. External LM decoding must be applied judiciously, as its effectiveness hinges on the match between speech and text resources. By articulating these trade-offs, the paper offers actionable guidance for building more effective ASR systems for underrepresented African languages and similar low-resource settings.

title: CAPTURE: A Benchmark and Evaluation for LVLMs in CAPTCHA Resolving
summary: Benefiting from strong and efficient multi-modal alignment strategies, Large Visual Language Models (LVLMs) are able to simulate human visual and reasoning capabilities, such as solving CAPTCHAs. However, existing benchmarks based on visual CAPTCHAs still face limitations. Previous studies, when designing benchmarks and datasets, customized them according to their research objectives. Consequently, these benchmarks cannot comprehensively cover all CAPTCHA types. Notably, there is a dearth of dedicated benchmarks for LVLMs. To address this problem, we introduce a novel CAPTCHA benchmark for the first time, named CAPTURE CAPTCHA for Testing Under Real-world Experiments, specifically for LVLMs. Our benchmark encompasses 4 main CAPTCHA types and 25 sub-types from 31 vendors. The diversity enables a multi-dimensional and thorough evaluation of LVLM performance. CAPTURE features extensive class variety, large-scale data, and unique LVLM-tailored labels, filling the gaps in previous research in terms of data comprehensiveness and labeling pertinence. When evaluated by this benchmark, current LVLMs demonstrate poor performance in solving CAPTCHAs.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CAPTURE, a comprehensive real-world CAPTCHA benchmark specifically designed to evaluate Large Visual Language Models (LVLMs), revealing that current LVLMs still perform poorly on diverse, real-world CAPTCHA types.
AI.motivation: Existing visual CAPTCHA benchmarks are fragmented, usually tailored to specific research goals, and fail to comprehensively cover the wide variety of CAPTCHA types used in practice. There is also a lack of benchmarks specifically designed for LVLMs, meaning current evaluations do not reflect real-world difficulty or support systematic, multi-dimensional assessment of LVLM capabilities on CAPTCHAs.
AI.method: The authors build CAPTURE, a new benchmark that aggregates CAPTCHAs from 31 real-world vendors, organized into 4 main types and 25 sub-types. They design LVLM-oriented labels and a large-scale, diverse dataset to enable detailed and multi-dimensional evaluation of LVLMs across many CAPTCHA variants. They then test existing LVLMs on this benchmark to measure their performance.
AI.result: CAPTURE provides a large, diverse, and finely labeled collection of CAPTCHAs that covers significantly more types and real-world sources than prior benchmarks. When evaluated on CAPTURE, current state-of-the-art LVLMs show generally poor performance in solving the included CAPTCHAs, especially across the full range of types and sub-types.
AI.conclusion: CAPTURE fills a major gap in CAPTCHA evaluation by offering a comprehensive, LVLM-focused benchmark drawn from diverse real-world vendors and CAPTCHA designs. The experimental results indicate that despite their strong general multimodal abilities, current LVLMs are far from reliably solving real-world CAPTCHAs, highlighting substantial remaining challenges and opportunities for future research on robust multi-modal reasoning and security-sensitive tasks.

title: MedBioRAG: Semantic Search and Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Large Language Models for Medical and Biological QA
comment: Submitted to ACL 2025. 9 pages, 4 figures, 5 tables (including 2 appendix tables)
summary: Recent advancements in retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) have significantly enhanced the ability of large language models (LLMs) to perform complex question-answering (QA) tasks. In this paper, we introduce MedBioRAG, a retrieval-augmented model designed to improve biomedical QA performance through a combination of semantic and lexical search, document retrieval, and supervised fine-tuning. MedBioRAG efficiently retrieves and ranks relevant biomedical documents, enabling precise and context-aware response generation. We evaluate MedBioRAG across text retrieval, close-ended QA, and long-form QA tasks using benchmark datasets such as NFCorpus, TREC-COVID, MedQA, PubMedQA, and BioASQ. Experimental results demonstrate that MedBioRAG outperforms previous state-of-the-art (SoTA) models and the GPT-4o base model in all evaluated tasks. Notably, our approach improves NDCG and MRR scores for document retrieval, while achieving higher accuracy in close-ended QA and ROUGE scores in long-form QA. Our findings highlight the effectiveness of semantic search-based retrieval and LLM fine-tuning in biomedical applications.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes MedBioRAG, a specialized retrieval-augmented generation system that combines semantic and lexical search plus fine-tuned LLMs to improve biomedical question answering, outperforming prior SoTA and GPT-4o on multiple retrieval and QA benchmarks.
AI.motivation: General-purpose RAG and LLMs, including strong base models, still struggle to achieve optimal performance on specialized biomedical QA tasks that require precise, evidence-grounded answers from domain-specific literature. Existing models may not fully exploit both semantic and lexical retrieval signals or may lack domain-adapted fine-tuning. There is a need for a tailored approach that can more accurately retrieve and use biomedical documents to improve QA quality across different task formats.
AI.method: The authors design MedBioRAG, a retrieval-augmented model that integrates (1) semantic search and lexical search to retrieve relevant biomedical documents, (2) a ranking mechanism to prioritize the most useful documents, and (3) supervised fine-tuning of the LLM for biomedical QA. They evaluate MedBioRAG on a suite of biomedical benchmarks (NFCorpus, TREC-COVID, MedQA, PubMedQA, BioASQ) across three task types: text retrieval, close-ended QA, and long-form QA, comparing against SoTA systems and the GPT-4o base model using metrics such as NDCG, MRR, accuracy, and ROUGE.
AI.result: Across all evaluated tasks and datasets, MedBioRAG consistently surpasses previous state-of-the-art models and the GPT-4o base model. It yields higher NDCG and MRR scores in document retrieval, improved accuracy in close-ended QA, and better ROUGE scores for long-form QA, indicating more relevant retrieval and higher quality generated answers.
AI.conclusion: MedBioRAG demonstrates that combining semantic search-based retrieval with supervised fine-tuning of LLMs is highly effective for biomedical QA. The model’s superior performance on diverse retrieval and QA benchmarks suggests that domain-specialized RAG systems can substantially improve the precision and usefulness of LLM-generated answers in biomedical applications.

title: Towards Trustworthy Multi-Turn LLM Agents via Behavioral Guidance
comment: Accepted to AAAI 2026 Workshop on Trust and Control in Agentic AI (TrustAgent)
summary:
Large Language Models demonstrate strong reasoning and generation abilities, yet their behavior in multi-turn tasks often lacks reliability and verifiability. We present a task completion framework that enables LLM-based agents to act under explicit behavioral guidance in environments described by reinforcement learning formalisms with defined observation, action, and reward signals.
  The framework integrates three components: a lightweight task profiler that selects reasoning and generation strategies, a reasoning module that learns verifiable observation - action mappings, and a generation module that enforces constraint-compliant outputs through validation or deterministic synthesis. We show that as the agent interacts with the environment, these components co-evolve, yielding trustworthy behavior.

AI.tldr: A framework for making LLM-based agents more reliable and verifiable in multi-turn, RL-style environments by profiling tasks, learning verifiable policies, and constraining outputs.
AI.motivation: LLMs are powerful at reasoning and text generation, but in multi-step interactive settings (like RL environments) they can behave unpredictably, violate constraints, or produce unverifiable decisions. There is a need for a principled way to guide LLM behavior so that actions are reliable, aligned with environment rules, and amenable to verification, especially when observations, actions, and rewards are formally defined.
AI.method: The authors define a task completion framework tailored to environments modeled with reinforcement learning formalisms. It has three co-operating components: (1) a lightweight task profiler that, given the current task and context, selects appropriate reasoning and generation strategies for the agent; (2) a reasoning module that learns and maintains explicit, verifiable mappings from observations to actions, making the agent’s decision process checkable; and (3) a generation module that ensures outputs obey constraints either by validating generated content and rejecting non-compliant outputs or by deterministically synthesizing outputs that necessarily satisfy the constraints. These components update and adapt as the agent repeatedly interacts with the environment.
AI.result: The integrated framework produces LLM-based agents whose behavior becomes more trustworthy over time. As the agent interacts with the environment and receives feedback, the profiling, reasoning, and generation components adapt together, leading to more consistent adherence to constraints, more reliable observation-to-action mappings, and improved verifiability of behavior in the tested RL-style environments.
AI.conclusion: By combining task profiling, verifiable reasoning, and constraint-enforcing generation within an RL-style formal environment, the framework enables LLM agents to evolve towards trustworthy, reliably verifiable behavior during multi-turn interactions. This suggests a viable path for deploying LLMs as agents in structured decision-making tasks where correctness and constraint satisfaction are critical.

title: KBQA-R1: Reinforcing Large Language Models for Knowledge Base Question Answering
summary: Knowledge Base Question Answering (KBQA) challenges models to bridge the gap between natural language and strict knowledge graph schemas by generating executable logical forms. While Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced this field, current approaches often struggle with a dichotomy of failure: they either generate hallucinated queries without verifying schema existence or exhibit rigid, template-based reasoning that mimics synthesized traces without true comprehension of the environment. To address these limitations, we present \textbf{KBQA-R1}, a framework that shifts the paradigm from text imitation to interaction optimization via Reinforcement Learning. Treating KBQA as a multi-turn decision process, our model learns to navigate the knowledge base using a list of actions, leveraging Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to refine its strategies based on concrete execution feedback rather than static supervision. Furthermore, we introduce \textbf{Referenced Rejection Sampling (RRS)}, a data synthesis method that resolves cold-start challenges by strictly aligning reasoning traces with ground-truth action sequences. Extensive experiments on WebQSP, GrailQA, and GraphQuestions demonstrate that KBQA-R1 achieves state-of-the-art performance, effectively grounding LLM reasoning in verifiable execution.

AI.tldr: They propose KBQA-R1, an RL-based framework for KBQA that treats query generation as a multi-turn decision process, uses GRPO to optimize actions from execution feedback, and introduces Referenced Rejection Sampling to create aligned training data, achieving SOTA on several benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing KBQA methods with LLMs either hallucinate queries that do not match the KB schema or rely on rigid, template-like reasoning traces that do not reflect real understanding. There is a need for methods that ground LLM reasoning in actual KB interaction and verifiable execution rather than static imitation learning, and that can handle cold-start training without misaligned synthetic traces.
AI.method: Model KBQA as a sequential decision-making problem where an agent interacts with a KB through a set of predefined actions to build executable logical forms. Use Reinforcement Learning with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to optimize the policy based on execution feedback from the KB instead of only supervised traces. To address cold-start, introduce Referenced Rejection Sampling (RRS) to synthesize training trajectories whose reasoning steps are strictly consistent with known ground-truth action sequences, providing high-quality initial data for RL fine-tuning.
AI.result: On three standard KBQA benchmarks—WebQSP, GrailQA, and GraphQuestions—the proposed KBQA-R1 framework achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming prior LLM-based and non-LLM methods. The experiments show improved grounding of reasoning in the KB and reduced hallucination, confirming the benefit of RL-based interaction and the RRS data synthesis approach.
AI.conclusion: KBQA-R1 demonstrates that shifting from imitation of text-based reasoning traces to reinforcement learning-based interaction with knowledge bases can substantially improve KBQA performance and reliability. By optimizing actions based on executable feedback and bootstrapping with well-aligned synthetic traces through RRS, the framework better grounds LLM reasoning in the KB schema and achieves SOTA results on multiple benchmarks, highlighting RL as a promising direction for KBQA with LLMs.

title: AgentBalance: Backbone-then-Topology Design for Cost-Effective Multi-Agent Systems under Budget Constraints
summary: Large Language Model (LLM)-based multi-agent systems (MAS) are becoming indispensable building blocks for web-scale applications such as web search, social network analytics, and online customer support, where cost-effectiveness is increasingly the primary constraint for large-scale deployment. While recent work improves MAS cost-effectiveness by shaping inter-agent communication topologies and selecting agent backbones, it rarely models and optimizes under explicit token-cost and latency budgets that reflect deployment constraints. This often leads to topology-first designs and suboptimal cost-effectiveness when budgets are binding. We present AgentBalance, a framework for constructing cost-effective MAS under explicit token-cost and latency budgets via a backbone-then-topology design. AgentBalance first performs backbone-oriented agent generation, constructing agents with heterogeneous backbones through LLM pool construction, pool selection, and role-backbone matching. It then performs adaptive MAS topology generation, guiding inter-agent communication via agent representation learning, gating, and latency-aware topology synthesis. Experiments on benchmarks with 14 candidate LLM backbones show that AgentBalance achieves up to 10% and 22% performance gains under matched token-cost and latency budgets, respectively, and yields strong AUC on performance-versus-budget curves across benchmarks. AgentBalance also functions as a plug-in for existing MAS, improving performance under the same token-cost and latency constraints, and it generalizes well to unseen LLMs for practical, budget-aware deployment. Code: https://github.com/usail-hkust/AgentBalance

AI.tldr: AgentBalance is a framework that designs multi-agent systems built from multiple LLMs to maximize task performance while staying within explicit token-cost and latency budgets.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM-based multi-agent systems often optimize architectures (e.g., communication topologies, backbone selection) without explicitly modeling real-world deployment constraints like token usage costs and latency. This can lead to suboptimal performance when strict budgets are enforced in web-scale applications such as search, social analytics, or customer support, where efficiency and responsiveness are crucial.
AI.method: AgentBalance follows a backbone-then-topology design pipeline. First, it does backbone-oriented agent generation: it builds a pool of candidate LLM backbones, selects an appropriate subset, and matches roles to backbones to form heterogeneous agents. Second, it performs adaptive MAS topology generation: it learns representations of agents, uses gating mechanisms to control inter-agent communication, and synthesizes communication topologies that are explicitly latency-aware while respecting token-cost constraints. The system searches over backbone and topology configurations to satisfy given budgets and optimize performance.
AI.result: On benchmarks using 14 candidate LLM backbones, AgentBalance improves performance under fixed budgets: up to 10% gain when token-cost is matched and up to 22% gain when latency is matched, compared to baselines. It also yields strong area under the performance-versus-budget curve, can be plugged into existing MAS to enhance them under the same constraints, and works well even on previously unseen LLMs.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly modeling token-cost and latency budgets in the design of LLM-based multi-agent systems yields more cost-effective and performant architectures. By first choosing heterogeneous LLM backbones and then adaptively synthesizing a latency-aware communication topology, AgentBalance provides a practical, pluggable framework for budget-aware MAS deployment that generalizes across models and tasks.

title: Back to the Baseline: Examining Baseline Effects on Explainability Metrics
summary: Attribution methods are among the most prevalent techniques in Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) and are usually evaluated and compared using Fidelity metrics, with Insertion and Deletion being the most popular. These metrics rely on a baseline function to alter the pixels of the input image that the attribution map deems most important. In this work, we highlight a critical problem with these metrics: the choice of a given baseline will inevitably favour certain attribution methods over others. More concerningly, even a simple linear model with commonly used baselines contradicts itself by designating different optimal methods. A question then arises: which baseline should we use? We propose to study this problem through two desirable properties of a baseline: (i) that it removes information and (ii) that it does not produce overly out-of-distribution (OOD) images. We first show that none of the tested baselines satisfy both criteria, and there appears to be a trade-off among current baselines: either they remove information or they produce a sequence of OOD images. Finally, we introduce a novel baseline by leveraging recent work in feature visualisation to artificially produce a model-dependent baseline that removes information without being overly OOD, thus improving on the trade-off when compared to other existing baselines. Our code is available at https://github.com/deel-ai-papers/Back-to-the-Baseline

AI.tldr: The paper shows that common fidelity metrics for XAI (Insertion/Deletion) are highly sensitive to the chosen baseline, making comparisons between attribution methods unreliable, and proposes a new, model-dependent baseline that better balances information removal and staying in-distribution.
AI.motivation: Attribution methods are widely used to explain model predictions and are often compared with fidelity metrics like Insertion and Deletion. These metrics require a baseline to replace important pixels, but the choice of baseline can bias which attribution method appears best. Even for a simple linear model, different popular baselines can declare different methods as optimal, undermining the reliability and fairness of current XAI evaluations. The authors want to understand and fix this baseline dependence.
AI.method: 1) Conceptually analyze Insertion/Deletion fidelity metrics and show how the baseline choice affects the evaluation of attribution methods. 2) Formalize two desirable properties of a baseline: (i) it should genuinely remove information, and (ii) it should avoid generating strongly out-of-distribution images along the insertion/deletion path. 3) Empirically test a range of commonly used baselines against these two criteria, demonstrating that none satisfy both: those that remove information tend to create OOD images, while those that stay in-distribution often fail to really erase information. 4) Propose a new, model-dependent baseline inspired by feature visualization that constructs artificial but model-aligned content for occluded regions, aiming to remove predictive information while remaining closer to the model’s data manifold. 5) Evaluate this new baseline in the standard fidelity framework and compare trade-offs versus existing baselines.
AI.result: The study reveals that current popular baselines systematically bias Insertion/Deletion fidelity metrics: different baselines can favor different attribution methods, even on simple linear models, leading to contradictory “best method” conclusions. Empirical analysis confirms that no tested baseline both effectively removes information and avoids highly OOD image sequences; there is a trade-off where improving one property worsens the other. The proposed feature-visualization-based, model-dependent baseline achieves a better balance on this trade-off, yielding sequences that are less OOD while still removing enough information, and thus providing more consistent and reliable fidelity evaluations across attribution methods.
AI.conclusion: Baseline choice is a critical, often overlooked factor in the evaluation of attribution methods using fidelity metrics such as Insertion and Deletion. Existing baselines either fail to remove sufficient information or produce out-of-distribution artifacts, causing biased and sometimes contradictory judgments about which attribution method is superior. By formalizing desirable baseline properties and demonstrating that widely used baselines do not satisfy them jointly, the paper motivates more principled baseline design. The introduced model-dependent, feature-visualization-based baseline improves the trade-off between information removal and staying in-distribution, leading to fairer and more trustworthy comparisons of attribution methods, and highlighting that any fidelity-based XAI evaluation must carefully justify its baseline choice.

title: MultiScript30k: Leveraging Multilingual Embeddings to Extend Cross Script Parallel Data
comment: 7 pages, 2 figures, 5 tables. Not published at any conference at this time
summary: Multi30k is frequently cited in the multimodal machine translation (MMT) literature, offering parallel text data for training and fine-tuning deep learning models. However, it is limited to four languages: Czech, English, French, and German. This restriction has led many researchers to focus their investigations only on these languages. As a result, MMT research on diverse languages has been stalled because the official Multi30k dataset only represents European languages in Latin scripts. Previous efforts to extend Multi30k exist, but the list of supported languages, represented language families, and scripts is still very short. To address these issues, we propose MultiScript30k, a new Multi30k dataset extension for global languages in various scripts, created by translating the English version of Multi30k (Multi30k-En) using NLLB200-3.3B. The dataset consists of over \(30000\) sentences and provides translations of all sentences in Multi30k-En into Ar, Es, Uk, Zh\_Hans and Zh\_Hant. Similarity analysis shows that Multi30k extension consistently achieves greater than \(0.8\) cosine similarity and symmetric KL divergence less than \(0.000251\) for all languages supported except Zh\_Hant which is comparable to the previous Multi30k extensions ArEnMulti30k and Multi30k-Uk. COMETKiwi scores reveal mixed assessments of MultiScript30k as a translation of Multi30k-En in comparison to the related work. ArEnMulti30k scores nearly equal MultiScript30k-Ar, but Multi30k-Uk scores $6.4\%$ greater than MultiScript30k-Uk per split.

AI.tldr: They build MultiScript30k, an extension of the Multi30k multimodal MT dataset with additional non‑Latin-script and diverse languages, automatically translated from English with NLLB and evaluated for quality and similarity.
AI.motivation: Existing multimodal machine translation work relies heavily on the Multi30k dataset, which only covers four European, Latin‑script languages. This limits research on multimodal models for more diverse languages and scripts, and previous extensions have only added a small number of new languages and families. A broader, script-diverse benchmark is needed to support global MMT research.
AI.method: They automatically translate the English portion of the Multi30k dataset (Multi30k-En) into several additional languages—Arabic, Spanish, Ukrainian, Simplified Chinese (Zh_Hans), and Traditional Chinese (Zh_Hant)—using the NLLB200-3.3B model. They then evaluate the resulting corpus via similarity analysis (cosine similarity and symmetric KL divergence between source and target embeddings/distributions) and by using COMETKiwi, a learned MT evaluation metric, comparing their scores to prior Multi30k extensions (ArEnMulti30k and Multi30k-Uk).
AI.result: The new MultiScript30k corpus contains over 30k parallel sentences for each of the added languages. Similarity analysis indicates strong alignment between the original English data and the new translations for all languages, with cosine similarity above 0.8 and symmetric KL divergence below 0.000251, except for Zh_Hant whose similarity is on par with earlier Multi30k extensions. COMETKiwi scores are mixed: Arabic quality is comparable to the existing ArEnMulti30k extension, while the prior human-created (or differently created) Ukrainian extension Multi30k-Uk scores on average 6.4% higher per split than the new MultiScript30k-Uk translations.
AI.conclusion: MultiScript30k provides a substantially broadened version of Multi30k, adding multiple new languages and scripts with reasonable automatic-translation quality. While automatic translation may not always match the quality of some existing human or higher-quality extensions (e.g., for Ukrainian), the dataset still offers a practical and widely usable resource to enable multimodal MT research for a more global and script-diverse set of languages.

title: Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning: A Practitioner's Guide to RL Training Recipes
summary: We introduce Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning, a 12.7B parameter language model designed to bridge the gap between open-weight systems and proprietary frontier models in complex reasoning and long-context understanding. Addressing the common challenges of model collapse and training instability in reasoning adaptation, we propose a comprehensive, reproducible training recipe spanning system, data, and algorithmic optimizations. Our approach combines memory-efficient infrastructure for 64K-token contexts using hybrid parallelism and kernel-level optimizations with a two-stage Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) curriculum that mitigates distribution mismatch through verified, aligned synthetic data. Furthermore, we detail a robust Reinforcement Learning Fine-Tuning (RLFT) pipeline that stabilizes training via difficulty-aware data filtering and mixed-policy trajectory reuse. Empirical results demonstrate that Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning achieves performance comparable to models with significantly larger parameter counts across mathematics, coding, and agentic benchmarks, offering the community a competitive open model and a practical blueprint for scaling reasoning capabilities under realistic compute constraints.

AI.tldr: Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning is a 12.7B-parameter open-weight language model that approaches frontier-model reasoning performance through a carefully engineered, reproducible training recipe for long-context (64K) reasoning.
AI.motivation: Open-weight models usually lag behind proprietary frontier systems in complex reasoning and long-context tasks, and attempts to adapt models for reasoning often suffer from model collapse and unstable training. The authors want to close this performance gap while using realistic compute budgets and provide a clear, reproducible path for others to scale reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: They build a 12.7B-parameter model with infrastructure optimized for 64K-token contexts using hybrid parallelism and kernel-level memory/throughput optimizations. On the algorithmic side, they design a two-stage Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) curriculum that uses verified, aligned synthetic data to reduce distribution mismatch, followed by a Reinforcement Learning Fine-Tuning (RLFT) pipeline. The RLFT pipeline incorporates difficulty-aware data filtering and mixed-policy trajectory reuse to stabilize optimization and avoid collapse during reasoning adaptation.
AI.result: The resulting Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning model reaches performance comparable to substantially larger models on benchmarks in mathematics, code generation, and agentic tasks, particularly in complex reasoning and long-context scenarios. This shows that their combination of system optimizations, SFT curriculum, and RLFT pipeline is effective under modest compute.
AI.conclusion: Motif-2-12.7B-Reasoning demonstrates that a carefully designed training and systems recipe can yield a mid-sized open-weight model with reasoning ability close to much larger proprietary systems. The work offers both a competitive open model and a practical, reproducible blueprint for others to scale reasoning-focused models efficiently and stably, especially under long-context and compute-constrained settings.

title: Applying NLP to iMessages: Understanding Topic Avoidance, Responsiveness, and Sentiment
summary: What is your messaging data used for? While many users do not often think about the information companies can gather based off of their messaging platform of choice, it is nonetheless important to consider as society increasingly relies on short-form electronic communication. While most companies keep their data closely guarded, inaccessible to users or potential hackers, Apple has opened a door to their walled-garden ecosystem, providing iMessage users on Mac with one file storing all their messages and attached metadata. With knowledge of this locally stored file, the question now becomes: What can our data do for us? In the creation of our iMessage text message analyzer, we set out to answer five main research questions focusing on topic modeling, response times, reluctance scoring, and sentiment analysis. This paper uses our exploratory data to show how these questions can be answered using our analyzer and its potential in future studies on iMessage data.

AI.tldr: The paper presents an iMessage text analyzer that extracts and analyzes messaging metadata from Apple’s locally stored iMessage database to explore conversation patterns, topics, responsiveness, reluctance, and sentiment.
AI.motivation: As society relies more on short-form electronic communication, large amounts of behavioral and linguistic data are captured by messaging platforms, usually inaccessible to users. Apple’s macOS stores iMessage data in a local file, creating an opportunity to examine what insights can be derived from one’s own messaging history, shifting the question from what companies can do with our data to what benefits users and researchers can gain from it.
AI.method: The authors leverage Apple’s local iMessage database file on Mac to build an analyzer that processes messages and their metadata. They implement modules for topic modeling, calculation of response times between participants, derivation of a ‘reluctance score’ (a proxy for hesitance or engagement), and sentiment analysis. Using exploratory data analysis, they apply these methods to real iMessage histories to demonstrate the analyzer’s capabilities and how the five research questions can be addressed.
AI.result: The analyzer can successfully read and interpret the locally stored iMessage data, extract conversation-level features, and produce interpretable outputs for topics discussed, temporal response patterns, reluctance metrics, and sentiment distributions. The exploratory results demonstrate that meaningful behavioral and linguistic patterns can be inferred from personal iMessage logs.
AI.conclusion: The study shows that personal iMessage data, accessible through Apple’s local message store on Mac, can be transformed into actionable insights using a custom analyzer. Their tool offers a proof-of-concept for future research utilizing iMessage metadata for understanding communication behavior and suggests broader potential for giving users analytic access to their own messaging data.

title: Three methods, one problem: Classical and AI approaches to no-three-in-line
summary: The No-Three-In-Line problem asks for the maximum number of points that can be placed on an n by n grid with no three collinear, representing a famous problem in combinatorial geometry. While classical methods like Integer Linear Programming (ILP) guarantee optimal solutions, they face exponential scaling with grid size, and recent advances in machine learning offer promising alternatives for pattern-based approximation. This paper presents the first systematic comparison of classical optimization and AI approaches to this problem, evaluating their performance against traditional algorithms. We apply PatternBoost transformer learning and reinforcement learning (PPO) to this problem for the first time, comparing them against ILP. ILP achieves provably optimal solutions up to 19 by 19 grids, while PatternBoost matches optimal performance up to 14 by 14 grids with 96% test loss reduction. PPO achieves perfect solutions on 10 by 10 grids but fails at 11 by 11 grids, where constraint violations prevent valid configurations. These results demonstrate that classical optimization remains essential for exact solutions while AI methods offer competitive performance on smaller instances, with hybrid approaches presenting the most promising direction for scaling to larger problem sizes.

AI.tldr: Compares classical Integer Linear Programming with modern AI methods (PatternBoost transformer and PPO reinforcement learning) on the No-Three-In-Line grid problem, showing ILP is best for exact solutions while AI scales better to moderately larger sizes and suggests hybrid methods for further scaling.
AI.motivation: The No-Three-In-Line problem is a classic combinatorial geometry question, but exact methods like ILP scale poorly as grid size grows. With recent advances in machine learning, there is a need to understand if AI-based methods can approximate or match optimal solutions more efficiently, and how they compare systematically with traditional optimization on this well-defined benchmark.
AI.method: The paper formulates the No-Three-In-Line problem on n×n grids and benchmarks three approaches: (1) Integer Linear Programming to obtain provably optimal solutions where feasible; (2) a PatternBoost transformer model trained to learn placement patterns and predict near-optimal point configurations; and (3) a PPO reinforcement learning agent that iteratively places points while being penalized for creating collinear triples. They compare solution quality, scalability, and constraint satisfaction across grid sizes.
AI.result: ILP finds provably optimal solutions up to 19×19 grids but becomes computationally challenging beyond that. PatternBoost matches optimal ILP solutions up to 14×14 grids and achieves a 96% reduction in test loss, indicating strong pattern learning and near-optimal performance. PPO attains perfect solutions on 10×10 grids but fails at 11×11 due to frequent constraint violations, leading to invalid configurations. Overall, AI methods perform competitively on small to moderate grids but degrade as constraints grow more complex.
AI.conclusion: Classical ILP remains indispensable for obtaining exact solutions to the No-Three-In-Line problem, especially when proofs of optimality are required. However, learned methods like PatternBoost and PPO show that AI can approximate optimal configurations effectively on smaller grids and offer potential scalability benefits. The findings suggest that hybrid strategies—using ILP for verification or refinement of AI-generated candidates—are a promising path to tackle larger grid sizes that are otherwise intractable for pure exact optimization.

title: Explanation Bias is a Product: Revealing the Hidden Lexical and Position Preferences in Post-Hoc Feature Attribution
summary: Good quality explanations strengthen the understanding of language models and data. Feature attribution methods, such as Integrated Gradient, are a type of post-hoc explainer that can provide token-level insights. However, explanations on the same input may vary greatly due to underlying biases of different methods. Users may be aware of this issue and mistrust their utility, while unaware users may trust them inadequately. In this work, we delve beyond the superficial inconsistencies between attribution methods, structuring their biases through a model- and method-agnostic framework of three evaluation metrics. We systematically assess both the lexical and position bias (what and where in the input) for two transformers; first, in a controlled, pseudo-random classification task on artificial data; then, in a semi-controlled causal relation detection task on natural data. We find that lexical and position biases are structurally unbalanced in our model comparison, with models that score high on one type score low on the other. We also find signs that methods producing anomalous explanations are more likely to be biased themselves.

AI.tldr: The paper studies why different feature attribution methods give inconsistent explanations for transformer models and proposes a framework to systematically characterize and compare their biases.
AI.motivation: Explanations from feature attribution methods (e.g., Integrated Gradients) for language models often disagree with each other, which reduces user trust and may mislead users who are unaware of these inconsistencies. There is a need to move beyond observing superficial differences and instead systematically understand and quantify the structural biases in these explanation methods.
AI.method: The authors propose a model- and method-agnostic framework based on three evaluation metrics to quantify biases in feature attribution explanations. They focus on two key types of bias—lexical bias (what tokens are highlighted) and position bias (where in the sequence tokens are highlighted). They then conduct controlled experiments: (1) a pseudo-random classification task on artificial data and (2) a semi-controlled causal relation detection task on natural data, comparing different attribution methods on two transformer models.
AI.result: The study reveals that lexical and position biases are not balanced across models: models that perform well (low bias) on one type typically perform poorly (high bias) on the other. Additionally, attribution methods that generate particularly anomalous or strange-looking explanations are found to be more likely to exhibit strong biases according to the proposed metrics.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that explanation methods for transformers exhibit structured lexical and positional biases that can be quantified with their framework, and that these biases trade off against each other across models. Moreover, visually or qualitatively anomalous explanations may signal stronger underlying bias. This highlights the need for more principled evaluation and selection of attribution methods, rather than relying on explanations at face value.

title: General-purpose AI models can generate actionable knowledge on agroecological crop protection
summary: Generative artificial intelligence (AI) offers potential for democratizing scientific knowledge and converting this to clear, actionable information, yet its application in agri-food science remains unexplored. Here, we verify the scientific knowledge on agroecological crop protection that is generated by either web-grounded or non-grounded large language models (LLMs), i.e., DeepSeek versus the free-tier version of ChatGPT. For nine globally limiting pests, weeds, and plant diseases, we assessed the factual accuracy, data consistency, and breadth of knowledge or data completeness of each LLM. Overall, DeepSeek consistently screened a 4.8-49.7-fold larger literature corpus and reported 1.6-2.4-fold more biological control agents or management solutions than ChatGPT. As a result, DeepSeek reported 21.6% higher efficacy estimates, exhibited greater laboratory-to-field data consistency, and showed more realistic effects of pest identity and management tactics. However, both models hallucinated, i.e., fabricated fictitious agents or references, reported on implausible ecological interactions or outcomes, confused old and new scientific nomenclatures, and omitted data on key agents or solutions. Despite these shortcomings, both LLMs correctly reported low-resolution efficacy trends. Overall, when paired with rigorous human oversight, LLMs may pose a powerful tool to support farm-level decision-making and unleash scientific creativity.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how accurately and comprehensively two large language models (DeepSeek and free ChatGPT) can summarize and convert scientific knowledge on agroecological crop protection into actionable advice, finding that web-grounded DeepSeek performs better overall but both models still hallucinate and need human oversight.
AI.motivation: To understand whether generative AI, specifically large language models, can reliably democratize and operationalize scientific knowledge for agri-food systems, especially in the underexplored area of agroecological crop protection. The authors want to know if LLMs can support farm-level decision-making and scientific innovation without compromising on factual accuracy and ecological realism.
AI.method: The authors compared two LLMs: a web-grounded model (DeepSeek) and a non-grounded, free-tier ChatGPT. For nine globally important pests, weeds, and plant diseases, they queried both models and systematically evaluated (1) factual accuracy, (2) data consistency (e.g., between lab and field efficacy), and (3) breadth of knowledge or data completeness (size of literature base, number of biological control agents and management solutions reported). They also examined hallucinations, nomenclature errors, and omissions of key agents or solutions, and compared the efficacy patterns reported by each model.
AI.result: DeepSeek accessed and screened a 4.8–49.7 times larger literature corpus than ChatGPT and reported 1.6–2.4 times more biological control agents or management solutions. Consequently, DeepSeek produced efficacy estimates that were on average 21.6% higher, with better consistency between laboratory and field data and more realistic variation due to pest identity and management tactics. However, both models exhibited hallucinations (fabricated agents and references), misreported ecological interactions, confused old and new scientific names, and omitted important control options. Despite these issues, both models captured correct low-resolution patterns of efficacy (broad trends rather than precise values).
AI.conclusion: Web-grounded LLMs like DeepSeek can retrieve and synthesize a broader and more detailed body of agroecological crop protection knowledge than a non-grounded free ChatGPT, yielding more realistic and internally consistent recommendations. Nonetheless, systematic hallucinations and omissions mean that neither model is currently reliable as a stand-alone decision tool. With rigorous human oversight and expert validation, LLMs can augment farm-level decision-making and foster scientific creativity, but they must be treated as assistive, not authoritative, systems.

title: FIBER: A Multilingual Evaluation Resource for Factual Inference Bias
summary: Large language models are widely used across domains, yet there are concerns about their factual reliability and biases. Factual knowledge probing offers a systematic means to evaluate these aspects. Most existing benchmarks focus on single-entity facts and monolingual data. We therefore present FIBER, a multilingual benchmark for evaluating factual knowledge in single- and multi-entity settings. The dataset includes sentence completion, question-answering, and object-count prediction tasks in English, Italian, and Turkish. Using FIBER, we examine whether the prompt language induces inference bias in entity selection and how large language models perform on multi-entity versus single-entity questions. The results indicate that the language of the prompt can influence the model's generated output, particularly for entities associated with the country corresponding to that language. However, this effect varies across different topics such that 31% of the topics exhibit factual inference bias score greater than 0.5. Moreover, the level of bias differs across languages such that Turkish prompts show higher bias compared to Italian in 83% of the topics, suggesting a language-dependent pattern. Our findings also show that models face greater difficulty when handling multi-entity questions than the single-entity questions. Model performance differs across both languages and model sizes. The highest mean average precision is achieved in English, while Turkish and Italian lead to noticeably lower scores. Larger models, including Llama-3.1-8B and Qwen-2.5-7B, show consistently better performance than smaller 3B-4B models.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FIBER, a multilingual benchmark to probe factual knowledge and inference bias of large language models, covering single- and multi-entity tasks in English, Italian, and Turkish, and shows that prompt language and model size significantly affect factual accuracy and bias.
AI.motivation: Existing factual probing benchmarks for large language models mostly focus on monolingual, single-entity facts, leaving gaps in understanding how models behave across languages and in more complex, multi-entity settings, particularly regarding language-induced inference bias and reliability.
AI.method: The authors construct FIBER, a multilingual dataset with sentence completion, QA, and object-count tasks in English, Italian, and Turkish, designed to test single- and multi-entity factual knowledge. They then evaluate multiple LLMs of varying sizes on these tasks, systematically varying the prompt language and measuring factual accuracy, bias in entity selection (factual inference bias score), and performance differences between single- and multi-entity questions.
AI.result: Experiments show that the prompt language measurably impacts which entities models select, especially those tied to the country associated with that language; 31% of topics have a factual inference bias score above 0.5. Bias strength varies by language, with Turkish prompts exhibiting higher bias than Italian in 83% of topics. Models perform worse on multi-entity than single-entity questions, English prompts yield the highest mean average precision, and larger models (e.g., Llama-3.1-8B, Qwen-2.5-7B) consistently outperform smaller 3B–4B models.
AI.conclusion: FIBER reveals that factual behavior of LLMs is both language- and task-dependent: prompt language can induce systematic inference biases toward country-associated entities, performance degrades on multi-entity reasoning, and there are clear disparities across languages and model sizes. The benchmark offers a structured way to assess and compare LLM factual reliability and bias in multilingual, multi-entity contexts.

title: BAID: A Benchmark for Bias Assessment of AI Detectors
comment: Accepted at the workshop on Agentic AI Benchmarks and Applications for Enterprise Tasks at AAAI 2026
summary: AI-generated text detectors have recently gained adoption in educational and professional contexts. Prior research has uncovered isolated cases of bias, particularly against English Language Learners (ELLs) however, there is a lack of systematic evaluation of such systems across broader sociolinguistic factors. In this work, we propose BAID, a comprehensive evaluation framework for AI detectors across various types of biases. As a part of the framework, we introduce over 200k samples spanning 7 major categories: demographics, age, educational grade level, dialect, formality, political leaning, and topic. We also generated synthetic versions of each sample with carefully crafted prompts to preserve the original content while reflecting subgroup-specific writing styles. Using this, we evaluate four open-source state-of-the-art AI text detectors and find consistent disparities in detection performance, particularly low recall rates for texts from underrepresented groups. Our contributions provide a scalable, transparent approach for auditing AI detectors and emphasize the need for bias-aware evaluation before these tools are deployed for public use.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces BAID, a large-scale framework and dataset to systematically audit AI-generated text detectors for sociolinguistic biases, revealing consistent performance disparities, especially for underrepresented groups.
AI.motivation: AI-generated text detectors are increasingly used in education and professional settings, but prior evidence of bias (e.g., against English Language Learners) is fragmented and narrow. There is no systematic, large-scale evaluation across a broad set of sociolinguistic factors, which is necessary to understand and mitigate unfair treatment of different user groups.
AI.method: The authors design BAID, an evaluation framework and dataset with over 200k text samples covering seven bias-relevant categories: demographics, age, educational grade level, dialect, formality, political leaning, and topic. For each sample, they also generate synthetic variants using prompts that preserve the original semantic content while encoding subgroup-specific writing styles. They then benchmark four open-source, state-of-the-art AI text detectors on this suite, analyzing detection metrics across groups to quantify disparities.
AI.result: Across the evaluated detectors, the authors observe consistent disparities in detection performance between subgroups, with particularly low recall for texts produced by underrepresented groups. This indicates that such detectors are more likely to misclassify genuine text from these groups as AI-generated or fail to correctly identify AI-generated content associated with them, revealing systematic bias rather than isolated anomalies.
AI.conclusion: BAID offers a scalable and transparent way to audit AI text detectors for a wide spectrum of sociolinguistic biases. The findings highlight that current detectors exhibit significant, structured disparities, underscoring that bias-aware, subgroup-sensitive evaluation should be a prerequisite before deploying these systems in public, high-stakes contexts such as education or the workplace.

title: SciLaD: A Large-Scale, Transparent, Reproducible Dataset for Natural Scientific Language Processing
summary: SciLaD is a novel, large-scale dataset of scientific language constructed entirely using open-source frameworks and publicly available data sources. It comprises a curated English split containing over 10 million scientific publications and a multilingual, unfiltered TEI XML split including more than 35 million publications. We also publish the extensible pipeline for generating SciLaD. The dataset construction and processing workflow demonstrates how open-source tools can enable large-scale, scientific data curation while maintaining high data quality. Finally, we pre-train a RoBERTa model on our dataset and evaluate it across a comprehensive set of benchmarks, achieving performance comparable to other scientific language models of similar size, validating the quality and utility of SciLaD. We publish the dataset and evaluation pipeline to promote reproducibility, transparency, and further research in natural scientific language processing and understanding including scholarly document processing.

AI.tldr: Introduces SciLaD, a large open scientific language dataset (45M+ papers total) plus an open pipeline, and shows its usefulness by pretraining and evaluating a RoBERTa model.
AI.motivation: Existing scientific language models and datasets are often built on restricted, proprietary, or partially closed data and pipelines, which limits reproducibility, extensibility, and multilingual coverage. There is a need for a large-scale, high-quality, fully open and reproducible scientific text resource that supports English and multilingual scientific NLP, as well as a transparent pipeline that others can reuse and extend.
AI.method: Construct a large dataset of scientific texts using only open-source tools and publicly available data. Build (1) a curated English split of 10M+ publications and (2) an unfiltered multilingual TEI XML split of 35M+ publications. Release the entire pipeline used to generate and process the dataset, emphasizing data curation and quality control. Then pre-train a RoBERTa model on SciLaD and evaluate it on a broad suite of scientific NLP benchmarks to assess performance and indirectly validate dataset quality.
AI.result: SciLaD contains over 45M scientific publications across its English and multilingual splits, built via an open, extensible pipeline. A RoBERTa model pre-trained on SciLaD attains performance comparable to other similarly sized scientific language models on many benchmarks, indicating that the dataset is of high quality and suitable for downstream scientific NLP tasks.
AI.conclusion: SciLaD provides a large-scale, open, and reproducible scientific language dataset and generation pipeline, supporting both English and multilingual research. The competitive performance of a RoBERTa model pre-trained on SciLaD validates the dataset’s utility. By releasing both the data and evaluation pipeline, the work aims to foster transparency, reproducibility, and further progress in scientific language processing and scholarly document understanding.

title: EmeraldMind: A Knowledge Graph-Augmented Framework for Greenwashing Detection
