summary: As AI and web agents become pervasive in decision-making, it is critical to design intelligent systems that not only support sustainability efforts but also guard against misinformation. Greenwashing, i.e., misleading corporate sustainability claims, poses a major challenge to environmental progress. To address this challenge, we introduce EmeraldMind, a fact-centric framework integrating a domain-specific knowledge graph with retrieval-augmented generation to automate greenwashing detection. EmeraldMind builds the EmeraldGraph from diverse corporate ESG (environmental, social, and governance) reports, surfacing verifiable evidence, often missing in generic knowledge bases, and supporting large language models in claim assessment. The framework delivers justification-centric classifications, presenting transparent, evidence-backed verdicts and abstaining responsibly when claims cannot be verified. Experiments on a new greenwashing claims dataset demonstrate that EmeraldMind achieves competitive accuracy, greater coverage, and superior explanation quality compared to generic LLMs, without the need for fine-tuning or retraining.

AI.tldr: EmeraldMind is a fact-centric framework that uses a domain-specific knowledge graph plus retrieval-augmented generation to detect and explain greenwashing in corporate sustainability claims.
AI.motivation: Greenwashing—misleading corporate sustainability claims—undermines genuine environmental progress and is hard to detect automatically because generic knowledge bases lack detailed, verifiable ESG evidence, and generic LLMs often hallucinate, lack transparency, and cannot reliably verify sustainability claims. There is a need for intelligent systems that both support sustainability goals and guard against misinformation in AI-driven decision-making.
AI.method: The authors construct EmeraldGraph, a domain-specific knowledge graph built from diverse corporate ESG reports. They integrate this with a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline, where large language models retrieve relevant, structured ESG evidence from EmeraldGraph to assess the truthfulness of corporate sustainability claims. EmeraldMind performs justification-centric classification: it uses retrieved evidence to classify claims as greenwashing or not, provides explicit evidence-backed justifications, and is designed to abstain when the claim cannot be reliably verified. Importantly, this framework works without fine-tuning or retraining the underlying LLMs by leveraging structured retrieval and reasoning over the ESG knowledge graph.
AI.result: On a newly curated dataset of greenwashing-related claims, EmeraldMind achieves accuracy comparable to or better than generic LLM baselines, covers a larger fraction of claims (greater coverage), and produces higher-quality, more transparent explanations. It attains these gains with no additional fine-tuning or retraining of the LLM, showing that domain-specific knowledge graph integration and RAG substantially enhance greenwashing detection and explanation quality.
AI.conclusion: EmeraldMind demonstrates that combining domain-specific ESG knowledge graphs with retrieval-augmented generation enables more reliable, transparent, and interpretable detection of greenwashing. By grounding LLM judgments in verifiable corporate ESG evidence and allowing for abstention when data are insufficient, the framework improves both performance and trustworthiness over generic LLM approaches. This suggests a promising direction for building fact-centric, justification-oriented AI systems to combat sustainability-related misinformation in real-world decision-making contexts.

title: Multi-Intent Spoken Language Understanding: Methods, Trends, and Challenges
summary: Multi-intent spoken language understanding (SLU) involves two tasks: multiple intent detection and slot filling, which jointly handle utterances containing more than one intent. Owing to this characteristic, which closely reflects real-world applications, the task has attracted increasing research attention, and substantial progress has been achieved. However, there remains a lack of a comprehensive and systematic review of existing studies on multi-intent SLU. To this end, this paper presents a survey of recent advances in multi-intent SLU. We provide an in-depth overview of previous research from two perspectives: decoding paradigms and modeling approaches. On this basis, we further compare the performance of representative models and analyze their strengths and limitations. Finally, we discuss the current challenges and outline promising directions for future research. We hope this survey will offer valuable insights and serve as a useful reference for advancing research in multi-intent SLU.

AI.tldr: Survey of recent advances in multi-intent spoken language understanding, covering decoding paradigms, modeling approaches, comparative performance, challenges, and future directions.
AI.motivation: Although multi-intent SLU is important for realistic user utterances and has seen substantial progress, there is no comprehensive and systematic review of existing approaches, creating a gap for researchers and practitioners who need an organized understanding of the field.
AI.method: Conducts a structured literature survey of multi-intent SLU methods, organizing prior work into two main dimensions—decoding paradigms and modeling approaches—then compares representative models empirically and qualitatively analyzes their pros and cons.
AI.result: Provides a taxonomy of existing multi-intent SLU methods, summarizes and compares their performance, and identifies strengths and weaknesses of different paradigms and models based on reported experimental results in the literature.
AI.conclusion: The survey synthesizes current knowledge on multi-intent SLU, highlights open challenges, and proposes promising research directions, intending to guide and inspire further advances in the field.

title: AI-MASLD Metabolic Dysfunction and Information Steatosis of Large Language Models in Unstructured Clinical Narratives
summary: This study aims to simulate real-world clinical scenarios to systematically evaluate the ability of Large Language Models (LLMs) to extract core medical information from patient chief complaints laden with noise and redundancy, and to verify whether they exhibit a functional decline analogous to Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD). We employed a cross-sectional analysis design based on standardized medical probes, selecting four mainstream LLMs as research subjects: GPT-4o, Gemini 2.5, DeepSeek 3.1, and Qwen3-Max. An evaluation system comprising twenty medical probes across five core dimensions was used to simulate a genuine clinical communication environment. All probes had gold-standard answers defined by clinical experts and were assessed via a double-blind, inverse rating scale by two independent clinicians. The results show that all tested models exhibited functional defects to varying degrees, with Qwen3-Max demonstrating the best overall performance and Gemini 2.5 the worst. Under conditions of extreme noise, most models experienced a functional collapse. Notably, GPT-4o made a severe misjudgment in the risk assessment for pulmonary embolism (PE) secondary to deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This research is the first to empirically confirm that LLMs exhibit features resembling metabolic dysfunction when processing clinical information, proposing the innovative concept of "AI-Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (AI-MASLD)". These findings offer a crucial safety warning for the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in healthcare, emphasizing that current LLMs must be used as auxiliary tools under human expert supervision, as there remains a significant gap between their theoretical knowledge and practical clinical application.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how well several large language models extract key clinical information from noisy patient complaints and introduces the concept of AI-MASLD to describe systematic performance degradation under information overload.
AI.motivation: To understand whether mainstream LLMs can reliably handle realistic, noisy clinical chief complaints and to see if their performance degrades in a patterned way analogous to metabolic dysfunction in human liver disease, raising safety concerns for clinical use.
AI.method: A cross-sectional evaluation using 20 standardized medical probe cases spanning five core dimensions of clinical reasoning. Four LLMs (GPT-4o, Gemini 2.5, DeepSeek 3.1, Qwen3-Max) were tested. Each probe had a gold-standard answer defined by clinicians. Two independent clinicians, blinded to model identity, used an inverse rating scale to assess model outputs in a simulated real-world clinical communication setting.
AI.result: All four LLMs showed functional defects in extracting and reasoning over core medical information, with Qwen3-Max performing best overall and Gemini 2.5 worst. Under extreme informational noise, most models demonstrated near-collapse of function. A notable critical error was GPT-4o’s serious misjudgment of pulmonary embolism risk in the context of deep vein thrombosis.
AI.conclusion: The study provides empirical evidence that LLMs show systematic performance degradation when processing noisy clinical information, analogous to metabolic dysfunction, motivating the new concept of AI-MASLD. It warns that current LLMs are not yet reliable as independent clinical decision-makers and should only be used as supervised assistive tools, given the substantial gap between their theoretical knowledge and safe, practical clinical performance.

title: Leveraging LLMs for Title and Abstract Screening for Systematic Review: A Cost-Effective Dynamic Few-Shot Learning Approach
summary: Systematic reviews are a key component of evidence-based medicine, playing a critical role in synthesizing existing research evidence and guiding clinical decisions. However, with the rapid growth of research publications, conducting systematic reviews has become increasingly burdensome, with title and abstract screening being one of the most time-consuming and resource-intensive steps. To mitigate this issue, we designed a two-stage dynamic few-shot learning (DFSL) approach aimed at improving the efficiency and performance of large language models (LLMs) in the title and abstract screening task. Specifically, this approach first uses a low-cost LLM for initial screening, then re-evaluates low-confidence instances using a high-performance LLM, thereby enhancing screening performance while controlling computational costs. We evaluated this approach across 10 systematic reviews, and the results demonstrate its strong generalizability and cost-effectiveness, with potential to reduce manual screening burden and accelerate the systematic review process in practical applications.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a dynamic two-stage few-shot learning framework using large language models to make systematic-review title/abstract screening more efficient and cost-effective, while maintaining high performance across multiple reviews.
AI.motivation: Systematic reviews are fundamental to evidence-based medicine but have become increasingly laborious due to the rapid growth of research publications. Title and abstract screening consumes substantial time and human resources, creating a bottleneck in producing up-to-date reviews. There is a need for methods that can reduce manual workload and computational cost while preserving accuracy in screening relevant studies.
AI.method: The authors design a two-stage Dynamic Few-Shot Learning (DFSL) workflow built on large language models. In stage one, a cheaper, lower-capacity LLM performs initial screening of titles and abstracts. The model also estimates confidence for each decision. Items judged to be low-confidence are then passed to stage two, where a more powerful but more expensive LLM re-evaluates them. The approach uses few-shot prompting, dynamically selecting examples, and a confidence-based routing mechanism to balance performance and cost.
AI.result: Across 10 different systematic reviews, the DFSL pipeline shows strong generalization, delivering high screening performance while reducing the reliance on the most expensive LLM. This leads to lower computational costs and reduced manual screening needs without sacrificing accuracy in identifying relevant studies.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DFSL approach can effectively combine low-cost and high-performance LLMs to streamline title and abstract screening in systematic reviews. It improves efficiency, controls computational expenses, and shows good generalizability across multiple review topics, indicating practical potential to lessen manual workload and speed up the systematic review process.

title: AI Benchmark Democratization and Carpentry
summary:
Benchmarks are a cornerstone of modern machine learning, enabling reproducibility, comparison, and scientific progress. However, AI benchmarks are increasingly complex, requiring dynamic, AI-focused workflows. Rapid evolution in model architectures, scale, datasets, and deployment contexts makes evaluation a moving target. Large language models often memorize static benchmarks, causing a gap between benchmark results and real-world performance.
  Beyond traditional static benchmarks, continuous adaptive benchmarking frameworks are needed to align scientific assessment with deployment risks. This calls for skills and education in AI Benchmark Carpentry. From our experience with MLCommons, educational initiatives, and programs like the DOE's Trillion Parameter Consortium, key barriers include high resource demands, limited access to specialized hardware, lack of benchmark design expertise, and uncertainty in relating results to application domains. Current benchmarks often emphasize peak performance on top-tier hardware, offering limited guidance for diverse, real-world scenarios.
  Benchmarking must become dynamic, incorporating evolving models, updated data, and heterogeneous platforms while maintaining transparency, reproducibility, and interpretability. Democratization requires both technical innovation and systematic education across levels, building sustained expertise in benchmark design and use. Benchmarks should support application-relevant comparisons, enabling informed, context-sensitive decisions. Dynamic, inclusive benchmarking will ensure evaluation keeps pace with AI evolution and supports responsible, reproducible, and accessible AI deployment. Community efforts can provide a foundation for AI Benchmark Carpentry.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that static AI benchmarks are no longer sufficient and proposes continuous, adaptive, and democratized benchmarking practices—termed "AI Benchmark Carpentry"—to better match real-world deployment and risks.
AI.motivation: Current AI benchmarks are static, easily memorized by large language models, and often focused on peak performance on elite hardware. This creates a gap between benchmark scores and real-world performance, and excludes many practitioners due to resource and expertise barriers. There is a need to realign benchmarking with rapidly evolving AI systems and deployment contexts.
AI.method: Conceptual and position-paper style: the authors synthesize experience from MLCommons, educational initiatives, and large-scale programs like the DOE’s Trillion Parameter Consortium to identify barriers in current benchmarking practices. They then outline principles and requirements for continuous, adaptive, and democratized benchmarking frameworks they call AI Benchmark Carpentry.
AI.result: The paper identifies key barriers—resource intensity, hardware access, lack of benchmark design expertise, and difficulty connecting results to application domains—and articulates requirements for future benchmarks: they must be dynamic (evolving models, data, and platforms), transparent, reproducible, interpretable, and accessible. It highlights that current emphasis on top-tier hardware limits usefulness for diverse real-world scenarios.
AI.conclusion: To keep pace with AI evolution and ensure responsible deployment, the community must move from static, peak-performance-centric benchmarks to dynamic, inclusive, and application-relevant benchmarking ecosystems. Building AI Benchmark Carpentry will require both technical innovations (frameworks and tools) and systematic education to cultivate broad expertise in benchmark design, interpretation, and use.

title: When Actions Teach You to Think: Reasoning-Action Synergy via Reinforcement Learning in Conversational Agents
summary: Supervised fine-tuning (SFT) has emerged as one of the most effective ways to improve the performance of large language models (LLMs) in downstream tasks. However, SFT can have difficulty generalizing when the underlying data distribution changes, even when the new data does not fall completely outside the training domain. Recent reasoning-focused models such as o1 and R1 have demonstrated consistent gains over their non-reasoning counterparts, highlighting the importance of reasoning for improved generalization and reliability. However, collecting high-quality reasoning traces for SFT remains challenging -- annotations are costly, subjective, and difficult to scale. To address this limitation, we leverage Reinforcement Learning (RL) to enable models to learn reasoning strategies directly from task outcomes. We propose a pipeline in which LLMs generate reasoning steps that guide both the invocation of tools (e.g., function calls) and the final answer generation for conversational agents. Our method employs Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with rewards designed around tool accuracy and answer correctness, allowing the model to iteratively refine its reasoning and actions. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach improves both the quality of reasoning and the precision of tool invocations, achieving a 1.5% relative improvement over the SFT model (trained without explicit thinking) and a 40% gain compared to the base of the vanilla Qwen3-1.7B model. These findings demonstrate the promise of unifying reasoning and action learning through RL to build more capable and generalizable conversational agents.

AI.tldr: They use reinforcement learning to teach LLMs to produce reasoning steps and call tools more accurately, improving over standard supervised fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Supervised fine-tuning boosts LLM performance but generalizes poorly when data distributions shift, and high-quality reasoning traces for SFT are expensive and hard to scale. Recent reasoning-centric models show that explicit reasoning is crucial, but there is no easy way to collect such traces for many tasks, especially those involving tool use.
AI.method: They introduce an RL-based pipeline where the LLM produces intermediate reasoning steps that determine both tool invocations (e.g., function calls) and final answers. The training uses Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), with reward signals based on how accurate the tools are used and how correct the final answers are. Through RL, the model iteratively refines its reasoning strategies and action sequences without relying on manually written chain-of-thought data.
AI.result: The RL-trained model shows better reasoning quality and more precise tool calls, yielding a 1.5% relative improvement over an SFT model that lacks explicit reasoning and a 40% gain over the vanilla Qwen3-1.7B base model.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement learning that jointly optimizes reasoning and tool-use actions can effectively replace expensive manual reasoning annotations, leading to more robust and generalizable conversational agents. Unifying reasoning and action learning via RL is a promising direction for future LLM development.

title: Causal Inference in Energy Demand Prediction
summary:
Energy demand prediction is critical for grid operators, industrial energy
  consumers, and service providers. Energy demand is influenced by multiple
  factors, including weather conditions (e.g. temperature, humidity, wind
  speed, solar radiation), and calendar information (e.g. hour of day and
  month of year), which further affect daily work and life schedules. These
  factors are causally interdependent, making the problem more complex than
  simple correlation-based learning techniques satisfactorily allow for. We
  propose a structural causal model that explains the causal relationship
  between these variables. A full analysis is performed to validate our causal
  beliefs, also revealing important insights consistent with prior studies.
  For example, our causal model reveals that energy demand responds to
  temperature fluctuations with season-dependent sensitivity. Additionally, we
  find that energy demand exhibits lower variance in winter due to the
  decoupling effect between temperature changes and daily activity patterns.
  We then build a Bayesian model, which takes advantage of the causal insights
  we learned as prior knowledge. The model is trained and tested on unseen
  data and yields state-of-the-art performance in the form of a 3.84 percent MAPE on
  the test set. The model also demonstrates strong robustness, as the
  cross-validation across two years of data yields an average MAPE of 3.88 percent.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a causally-informed Bayesian model for short-term energy demand forecasting that achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and robustness.
AI.motivation: Existing energy demand prediction methods largely rely on correlation-based machine learning that may not capture the true causal relationships among weather, calendar variables, human activity, and energy demand. This can limit interpretability, robustness, and generalization, especially when the underlying conditions shift (e.g., across seasons). The authors aim to build a forecasting model that is both accurate and causally grounded, improving reliability and providing insights into how different factors truly affect demand.
AI.method: The authors first construct a structural causal model (SCM) encoding hypothesized causal relationships between weather variables (temperature, humidity, wind speed, solar radiation), calendar information (hour, month), human activity patterns, and energy demand. They perform a full causal analysis to validate these assumptions and explore implications such as season-dependent temperature sensitivity and variance patterns. Using the insights from the SCM, they design a Bayesian forecasting model where the causal findings inform the priors and structure of the model. The model is then trained and evaluated on historical energy consumption and weather data across multiple years.
AI.result: The causally-informed Bayesian model achieves a Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of 3.84% on the held-out test set, which the authors claim is state-of-the-art for the considered task and dataset. Cross-validation over two years of data yields an average MAPE of 3.88%, indicating that the model maintains high predictive accuracy and robustness when evaluated under different temporal splits.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating explicit causal reasoning into energy demand forecasting via a structural causal model and translating that knowledge into a Bayesian predictive framework leads to both improved accuracy and stronger robustness compared with traditional correlation-based approaches. The analysis also yields interpretable domain insights, such as season-dependent responses of demand to temperature and lower winter variance due to decoupling between temperature and human activity patterns. This demonstrates the value of causally-informed modeling for operational energy demand forecasting.

title: AdaSD: Adaptive Speculative Decoding for Efficient Language Model Inference
summary: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable performance across a wide range of tasks, but their increasing parameter sizes significantly slow down inference. Speculative decoding mitigates this issue by leveraging a smaller draft model to predict candidate tokens, which are then verified by a larger target model. However, existing approaches often require additional training, extensive hyperparameter tuning, or prior analysis of models and tasks before deployment. In this paper, we propose Adaptive Speculative Decoding (AdaSD), a hyperparameter-free decoding scheme that dynamically adjusts generation length and acceptance criteria during inference. AdaSD introduces two adaptive thresholds: one to determine when to stop candidate token generation and another to decide token acceptance, both updated in real time based on token entropy and Jensen-Shannon distance. This approach eliminates the need for pre-analysis or fine-tuning and is compatible with off-the-shelf models. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaSD achieves up to 49\% speedup over standard speculative decoding while limiting accuracy degradation to under 2\%, making it a practical solution for efficient and adaptive LLM inference.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Speculative Decoding (AdaSD) makes LLM speculative decoding faster and easier to deploy by automatically adjusting how many draft tokens to propose and how strictly to accept them, without extra training or tuning.
AI.motivation: Speculative decoding uses a small draft model to speed up a large LLM, but current methods need extra training, hand-tuned hyperparameters, or prior task/model analysis, which complicates deployment and reduces generality. The authors want a plug-and-play speculative decoding method that works well out-of-the-box for off-the-shelf models while preserving accuracy and gaining speed.
AI.method: They design Adaptive Speculative Decoding (AdaSD), a hyperparameter-free scheme that adapts during inference. AdaSD uses two dynamic thresholds: (1) a stopping threshold to decide when the draft model should stop proposing additional candidate tokens, and (2) an acceptance threshold that decides whether the target model accepts those draft tokens. Both thresholds are updated online using token-level statistics—specifically token entropy and Jensen-Shannon distance between draft and target distributions—so the algorithm automatically calibrates itself as generation proceeds, with no prior tuning or fine-tuning required.
AI.result: On benchmark datasets, AdaSD yields up to 49% speedup compared to standard speculative decoding while keeping accuracy loss below 2%. These empirical results show that adaptively controlling proposal length and acceptance criteria can significantly improve efficiency with minimal performance degradation.
AI.conclusion: AdaSD provides an efficient and practical speculative decoding framework that is hyperparameter-free, adapts in real time using information-theoretic signals, and works directly with off-the-shelf LLMs. This makes it an attractive approach for faster LLM inference in real-world deployments where manual tuning and extra training are undesirable.

title: MedAI: Evaluating TxAgent's Therapeutic Agentic Reasoning in the NeurIPS CURE-Bench Competition
summary: Therapeutic decision-making in clinical medicine constitutes a high-stakes domain in which AI guidance interacts with complex interactions among patient characteristics, disease processes, and pharmacological agents. Tasks such as drug recommendation, treatment planning, and adverse-effect prediction demand robust, multi-step reasoning grounded in reliable biomedical knowledge. Agentic AI methods, exemplified by TxAgent, address these challenges through iterative retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). TxAgent employs a fine-tuned Llama-3.1-8B model that dynamically generates and executes function calls to a unified biomedical tool suite (ToolUniverse), integrating FDA Drug API, OpenTargets, and Monarch resources to ensure access to current therapeutic information. In contrast to general-purpose RAG systems, medical applications impose stringent safety constraints, rendering the accuracy of both the reasoning trace and the sequence of tool invocations critical. These considerations motivate evaluation protocols treating token-level reasoning and tool-usage behaviors as explicit supervision signals. This work presents insights derived from our participation in the CURE-Bench NeurIPS 2025 Challenge, which benchmarks therapeutic-reasoning systems using metrics that assess correctness, tool utilization, and reasoning quality. We analyze how retrieval quality for function (tool) calls influences overall model performance and demonstrate performance gains achieved through improved tool-retrieval strategies. Our work was awarded the Excellence Award in Open Science. Complete information can be found at https://curebench.ai/.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes an AI agent system (TxAgent) for therapeutic decision-making that uses retrieval-augmented generation with biomedical tools, and studies how tool-retrieval quality affects performance in the CURE-Bench NeurIPS 2025 Challenge.
AI.motivation: Therapeutic decision-making requires accurate, multi-step reasoning over up-to-date biomedical knowledge, where errors can have serious safety implications. Existing general RAG systems are not directly suited to these stringent medical demands, especially regarding faithful reasoning traces and safe tool usage. There is a need to understand and improve how agentic AI systems retrieve and use external biomedical tools in this high-stakes context, and to evaluate them with benchmarks tailored to therapeutic reasoning.
AI.method: The authors use TxAgent, a fine-tuned Llama-3.1-8B-based agent that performs iterative retrieval-augmented generation. It dynamically generates and executes function calls to a unified biomedical tool suite (ToolUniverse) that aggregates FDA Drug API, OpenTargets, and Monarch resources. They participate in the CURE-Bench NeurIPS 2025 Challenge, which evaluates systems on correctness, tool utilization, and reasoning quality. Within this setting, they treat token-level reasoning traces and tool-usage sequences as explicit supervision and systematically vary and analyze tool-retrieval strategies for function calls.
AI.result: They find that the quality of retrieval for function (tool) calls has a substantial influence on overall model performance in therapeutic reasoning tasks on CURE-Bench. By designing and applying improved tool-retrieval strategies within TxAgent, they achieve measurable performance gains across the benchmark’s metrics, including correctness and reasoning quality. Their work is recognized with the Excellence Award in Open Science in the challenge.
AI.conclusion: Accurate, safe therapeutic decision-making with agentic AI requires not only strong language models but also precise control over tool retrieval and usage. Treating reasoning traces and tool sequences as supervised signals and optimizing tool-retrieval strategies significantly improves performance in benchmarked therapeutic-reasoning tasks. The study underscores the importance of specialized evaluation frameworks like CURE-Bench for advancing reliable, tool-augmented medical AI systems.

title: CIP: A Plug-and-Play Causal Prompting Framework for Mitigating Hallucinations under Long-Context Noise
summary: Large language models often hallucinate when processing long and noisy retrieval contexts because they rely on spurious correlations rather than genuine causal relationships. We propose CIP, a lightweight and plug-and-play causal prompting framework that mitigates hallucinations at the input stage. CIP constructs a causal relation sequence among entities, actions, and events and injects it into the prompt to guide reasoning toward causally relevant evidence. Through causal intervention and counterfactual reasoning, CIP suppresses non causal reasoning paths, improving factual grounding and interpretability. Experiments across seven mainstream language models, including GPT-4o, Gemini 2.0 Flash, and Llama 3.1, show that CIP consistently enhances reasoning quality and reliability, achieving 2.6 points improvement in Attributable Rate, 0.38 improvement in Causal Consistency Score, and a fourfold increase in effective information density. API level profiling further shows that CIP accelerates contextual understanding and reduces end to end response latency by up to 55.1 percent. These results suggest that causal reasoning may serve as a promising paradigm for improving the explainability, stability, and efficiency of large language models.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CIP, a causal prompting framework that reduces hallucinations of large language models by injecting causal relations into prompts, thereby improving reasoning quality, grounding, and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Large language models hallucinate, especially with long and noisy retrieval contexts, because they often rely on spurious correlations instead of true causal relations. There is a need for a lightweight, model-agnostic method that can be applied at the prompt level to improve factual grounding, reliability, and interpretability without retraining models.
AI.method: CIP (Causal Intervention Prompting) builds an explicit causal relation sequence among entities, actions, and events extracted from the input context. This causal structure is added to the prompt to guide the model’s reasoning. It uses causal intervention and counterfactual reasoning within the prompt design to suppress non-causal reasoning paths and emphasize causally relevant evidence, in a plug-and-play way compatible with various LLM APIs.
AI.result: Across seven major LLMs, including GPT-4o, Gemini 2.0 Flash, and Llama 3.1, CIP improves multiple metrics: +2.6 points in Attributable Rate (better factual attribution), +0.38 in Causal Consistency Score (more causally coherent reasoning), and a 4x increase in effective information density (more useful content per token). API profiling also shows CIP can reduce end-to-end response latency by up to 55.1%, indicating faster, more focused contextual understanding.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly modeling and injecting causal relations at the prompt level can systematically reduce hallucinations, increase factual grounding, and improve efficiency of LLMs, without changing model weights. Causal reasoning is a promising, general paradigm for enhancing explainability, stability, and performance of large language models in real-world applications.

title: LegalRikai: Open Benchmark -- A Benchmark for Complex Japanese Corporate Legal Tasks
summary: This paper introduces LegalRikai: Open Benchmark, a new benchmark comprising four complex tasks that emulate Japanese corporate legal practices. The benchmark was created by legal professionals under the supervision of an attorney. This benchmark has 100 samples that require long-form, structured outputs, and we evaluated them against multiple practical criteria. We conducted both human and automated evaluations using leading LLMs, including GPT-5, Gemini 2.5 Pro, and Claude Opus 4.1. Our human evaluation revealed that abstract instructions prompted unnecessary modifications, highlighting model weaknesses in document-level editing that were missed by conventional short-text tasks. Furthermore, our analysis reveals that automated evaluation aligns well with human judgment on criteria with clear linguistic grounding, and assessing structural consistency remains a challenge. The result demonstrates the utility of automated evaluation as a screening tool when expert availability is limited. We propose a dataset evaluation framework to promote more practice-oriented research in the legal domain.

AI.tldr: Introduces LegalRikai: Open Benchmark, a Japanese corporate-law benchmark with four complex, practice-oriented tasks and 100 long-form, structured samples, evaluated with both humans and automated metrics on top LLMs.
AI.motivation: Existing legal NLP/LLM benchmarks are mostly short-text, synthetic, or not closely aligned with real corporate legal workflows, so they fail to reveal weaknesses in document-level editing and structure-sensitive reasoning. There is a need for a high-quality, expert-curated benchmark that reflects Japanese corporate legal practice and supports practice-oriented research and evaluation of LLMs.
AI.method: Legal professionals, under attorney supervision, designed four complex tasks that mirror real Japanese corporate legal work and assembled 100 examples requiring long-form, structured outputs. They defined multiple practical evaluation criteria, then ran experiments with leading LLMs (GPT-5, Gemini 2.5 Pro, Claude Opus 4.1), performing both human evaluation and automated evaluation. They compared human judgments with automatic metrics to analyze where they align or diverge, especially on linguistically grounded criteria versus structural consistency.
AI.result: Human evaluation showed that when given abstract instructions, LLMs often make unnecessary modifications in document-level editing tasks, revealing weaknesses not captured by standard short-text benchmarks. Automated evaluation correlated well with human judgment on criteria that have clear linguistic grounding but struggled to reliably assess structural consistency. Overall, the benchmark exposed nuanced performance differences across models and tasks and demonstrated that automated metrics can function as an effective first-pass screening tool when expert time is scarce.
AI.conclusion: LegalRikai: Open Benchmark offers a realistic, practice-oriented evaluation suite for Japanese corporate legal tasks, highlighting current LLM limitations in document-level editing and structural consistency. Automated evaluation can supplement but not fully replace expert review, especially for structure-heavy aspects. The authors propose their dataset and evaluation framework as infrastructure to drive more practice-oriented legal AI research and more reliable benchmarking of LLMs in real-world corporate legal settings.

title: qa-FLoRA: Data-free query-adaptive Fusion of LoRAs for LLMs
summary: The deployment of large language models for specialized tasks often requires domain-specific parameter-efficient finetuning through Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) modules. However, effectively fusing these adapters to handle complex, multi-domain composite queries remains a critical challenge. Existing LoRA fusion approaches either use static weights, which assign equal relevance to each participating LoRA, or require data-intensive supervised training for every possible LoRA combination to obtain respective optimal fusion weights. We propose qa-FLoRA, a novel query-adaptive data-and-training-free method for LoRA fusion that dynamically computes layer-level fusion weights by measuring distributional divergence between the base model and respective adapters. Our approach eliminates the need for composite training data or domain-representative samples, making it readily applicable to existing adapter collections. Extensive experiments across nine multilingual composite tasks spanning mathematics, coding, and medical domains, show that qa-FLoRA outperforms static fusion by ~5% with LLaMA-2 and ~6% with LLaMA-3, and the training-free baselines by ~7% with LLaMA-2 and ~10% with LLaMA-3, while significantly closing the gap with supervised baselines. Further, layer-level analysis of our fusion weights reveals interpretable fusion patterns, demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach for robust multi-domain adaptation.

AI.tldr: qa-FLoRA is a training-free, query-adaptive method to fuse multiple LoRA adapters so large language models can better answer complex, multi-domain queries.
AI.motivation: Deploying LLMs in real applications often needs many domain-specific LoRA adapters (e.g., for math, code, medicine). When a user query spans multiple domains, the model must effectively combine these adapters. Existing fusion methods either use fixed, non-adaptive weights or require supervised training for every adapter combination, which is costly and scales poorly. There is a need for a scalable, data-free way to adaptively fuse adapters per query.
AI.method: The authors introduce qa-FLoRA, which computes fusion weights for each layer of the model on the fly, conditioned on the query. It measures the distributional divergence between the base model and each LoRA-augmented model, using this divergence to determine how much each adapter should contribute at each layer. This process is training-free and does not require composite or domain-representative data, making it directly applicable to existing LoRA collections.
AI.result: On nine multilingual composite tasks that mix mathematics, coding, and medical domains, qa-FLoRA consistently outperforms static fusion by about 5% with LLaMA-2 and 6% with LLaMA-3, and surpasses other training-free fusion baselines by about 7% (LLaMA-2) and 10% (LLaMA-3). Its performance approaches that of supervised fusion methods without needing extra data or training.
AI.conclusion: qa-FLoRA provides an effective, scalable solution for multi-domain adaptation of LLMs by enabling query-adaptive, layer-wise fusion of LoRA adapters without additional data or training. It improves over static and training-free baselines, narrows the gap with supervised methods, and exhibits interpretable fusion patterns that align with domain usage across layers.

title: Mining Legal Arguments to Study Judicial Formalism
summary: Courts must justify their decisions, but systematically analyzing judicial reasoning at scale remains difficult. This study refutes claims about formalistic judging in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) by developing automated methods to detect and classify judicial reasoning in Czech Supreme Courts' decisions using state-of-the-art natural language processing methods. We create the MADON dataset of 272 decisions from two Czech Supreme Courts with expert annotations of 9,183 paragraphs with eight argument types and holistic formalism labels for supervised training and evaluation. Using a corpus of 300k Czech court decisions, we adapt transformer LLMs for Czech legal domain by continued pretraining and experiment with methods to address dataset imbalance including asymmetric loss and class weighting. The best models successfully detect argumentative paragraphs (82.6\% macro-F1), classify traditional types of legal argument (77.5\% macro-F1), and classify decisions as formalistic/non-formalistic (83.2\% macro-F1). Our three-stage pipeline combining ModernBERT, Llama 3.1, and traditional feature-based machine learning achieves promising results for decision classification while reducing computational costs and increasing explainability. Empirically, we challenge prevailing narratives about CEE formalism. This work shows that legal argument mining enables reliable judicial philosophy classification and shows the potential of legal argument mining for other important tasks in computational legal studies. Our methodology is easily replicable across jurisdictions, and our entire pipeline, datasets, guidelines, models, and source codes are available at https://github.com/trusthlt/madon.

AI.tldr: The paper builds and fine-tunes NLP models on a new Czech legal-argument dataset to automatically detect argument types and levels of formalism in Supreme Court decisions, empirically challenging the view that Central and Eastern European judging is predominantly formalistic.
AI.motivation: Systematically studying how judges reason in written decisions is difficult at scale, especially in Central and Eastern Europe where there are strong claims that courts are overly formalistic but limited empirical, fine-grained evidence. Manual analysis does not scale and existing automated tools are not tailored to Czech legal texts or to nuanced argument-type classification. The authors aim to provide data, methods, and empirical results to rigorously test narratives about judicial formalism and enable broader computational legal studies.
AI.method: The authors construct the MADON dataset with expert-annotated paragraphs from 272 decisions of two Czech Supreme Courts, labeling eight argument types and overall decision formalism. They then adapt transformer-based language models to the Czech legal domain using continued pretraining on a large corpus (~300k) of court decisions. For supervised tasks, they address label imbalance using techniques like asymmetric loss and class weighting. They design a three-stage pipeline: (1) detect argumentative paragraphs, (2) classify paragraph-level legal argument types, and (3) classify entire decisions as formalistic or non-formalistic, combining ModernBERT, Llama 3.1, and traditional feature-based ML to balance performance, efficiency, and interpretability.
AI.result: The best models reach macro-F1 scores of about 82.6% for detecting argumentative paragraphs, 77.5% for classifying types of legal argument, and 83.2% for classifying decisions as formalistic vs. non-formalistic. The multi-stage pipeline using ModernBERT, Llama 3.1, and classical ML methods performs well for decision classification while lowering computational cost and improving explainability. The resulting tools, data, and codebase provide a strong baseline for legal argument mining in Czech and potentially other jurisdictions.
AI.conclusion: Automated legal argument mining using adapted transformer models can reliably identify argument structures and judicial philosophy (formalism vs. non-formalism) in Czech Supreme Court decisions. The empirical findings undermine simplistic narratives of pervasive formalism in Central and Eastern Europe and demonstrate that scalable, reproducible NLP methods can support more nuanced computational legal research. The publicly released MADON dataset, models, and pipeline are intended to be reused and replicated across jurisdictions for similar studies of judicial reasoning.

title: Improving Translation Quality by Selecting Better Data for LLM Fine-Tuning: A Comparative Analysis
comment: To appear at IEEE Big Data 2025
summary: We investigated the impact of data selection on machine translation fine-tuning for open LLMs. Using Japanese-English corpora, we compare five selectors: TF-IDF, COMET Kiwi, QuRate, FD-Score, and random selection, under controlled training conditions. We observed that semantic selectors consistently outperform lexical and geometry-based heuristics, and that even when the selected data differ by less than 3%, the impact on model performance is substantial, underscoring the sensitivity of fine-tuning to data quality.

AI.tldr: Study on how different data selection methods affect fine-tuning quality of Japanese-English MT for open LLMs.
AI.motivation: Fine-tuning LLMs for machine translation is highly sensitive to the quality and composition of training data, but practitioners often rely on simple or ad-hoc data selection methods. The paper aims to systematically understand how various automatic data selection strategies impact translation performance when resources are limited or when one must choose a subset of available bitext.
AI.method: Use Japanese-English parallel corpora to fine-tune open-source LLMs for MT under strictly controlled setups (same model, budget, and training conditions). Compare five data selection strategies: TF-IDF (lexical similarity-based), COMET Kiwi (semantic quality-based), QuRate (semantic/relevance-based), FD-Score (geometry / representation-based criterion), and random sampling. Evaluate fine-tuned models on standard translation benchmarks to measure how different selectors influence final performance while keeping the amount of training data nearly constant (differences under 3%).
AI.result: Semantic-based selectors such as COMET Kiwi and QuRate consistently yield better translation performance than lexical similarity-based TF-IDF, geometry-based FD-Score, or random selection. The study finds that even very small differences in which training examples are selected (less than 3% variation in data) can lead to large differences in downstream MT quality.
AI.conclusion: Data selection strategy is a critical factor in fine-tuning open LLMs for machine translation: semantic-aware selectors are more effective than lexical or purely geometric heuristics, and models are highly sensitive to relatively small changes in the training subset. Practitioners should prioritize high-quality semantic selection methods when curating fine-tuning data for MT tasks.

title: Minimal Clips, Maximum Salience: Long Video Summarization via Key Moment Extraction
summary: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are able to process increasingly longer videos. Yet, important visual information is easily lost throughout the entire context and missed by VLMs. Also, it is important to design tools that enable cost-effective analysis of lengthy video content. In this paper, we propose a clip selection method that targets key video moments to be included in a multimodal summary. We divide the video into short clips and generate compact visual descriptions of each using a lightweight video captioning model. These are then passed to a large language model (LLM), which selects the K clips containing the most relevant visual information for a multimodal summary. We evaluate our approach on reference clips for the task, automatically derived from full human-annotated screenplays and summaries in the MovieSum dataset. We further show that these reference clips (less than 6% of the movie) are sufficient to build a complete multimodal summary of the movies in MovieSum. Using our clip selection method, we achieve a summarization performance close to that of these reference clips while capturing substantially more relevant video information than random clip selection. Importantly, we maintain low computational cost by relying on a lightweight captioning model.

AI.tldr: They propose a method to select the most informative clips from long videos for multimodal summarization, using cheap captions plus an LLM, and show it nearly matches human-derived reference clips while being much more efficient than processing the full video.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language models can take long video inputs but still miss important visual details, and fully processing long videos is computationally expensive. There is a need for a principled and cost-effective way to identify which short segments of a long video contain the key visual content needed to generate accurate multimodal summaries.
AI.method: The video is split into short clips. A lightweight video captioning model generates compact textual descriptions for each clip. These clip-level captions are then fed into a large language model, which selects the K clips that contain the most relevant visual information for inclusion in a multimodal summary. The method is evaluated by comparing the selected clips to automatically derived reference clips obtained from full human-annotated screenplays and summaries in the MovieSum dataset, and by measuring summarization performance when only the selected clips are used.
AI.result: The authors show that a small set of reference clips, comprising less than 6% of a movie, is enough to build a complete multimodal summary in MovieSum. Their clip selection method, based on lightweight captions plus LLM selection, achieves summarization performance close to that of using the reference clips, and significantly outperforms random clip selection in terms of capturing relevant video information, all while using much lower computational resources than methods that would process the entire video with heavy models.
AI.conclusion: A two-stage clip selection approach—lightweight captioning followed by LLM-based importance ranking—can effectively identify the key moments in long videos needed for multimodal summarization. This yields summaries that are nearly as good as those based on ideal human-derived reference clips, while being far more computationally efficient. Thus, targeted clip selection is a practical strategy for cost-effective analysis of lengthy video content with vision-language models.

title: Does Less Hallucination Mean Less Creativity? An Empirical Investigation in LLMs
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding and reasoning, but suffer from hallucination: the generation of factually incorrect content. While numerous methods have been developed to reduce hallucinations, their impact on creative generations remains unexplored. This gap is particularly critical for AI-assisted scientific discovery, which requires both factual accuracy and creative hypothesis generation. We investigate how three hallucination-reduction techniques: Chain of Verification (CoVe), Decoding by Contrasting Layers (DoLa), and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), affect creativity in LLMs. Evaluating multiple model families (LLaMA, Qwen, Mistral) at varying scales (1B - 70B parameters) on two creativity benchmarks (NeoCoder and CS4), we find that these methods have opposing effects on divergent creativity. CoVe enhances divergent thinking, DoLa suppresses it, and RAG shows minimal impact. Our findings provide guidance for selecting appropriate hallucination-reduction methods in scientific applications, where the balance between factual accuracy and creative exploration is crucial.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how three hallucination-reduction methods (CoVe, DoLa, RAG) impact LLM creativity and finds they have different effects, especially on divergent thinking.
AI.motivation: LLMs hallucinate, which is problematic, but existing work on reducing hallucinations has not checked how these fixes affect the model’s ability to be creatively generative—crucial for scientific discovery that needs both accuracy and novel ideas.
AI.method: Evaluate three hallucination-mitigation techniques—Chain of Verification (CoVe), Decoding by Contrasting Layers (DoLa), and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)—across multiple LLM families (LLaMA, Qwen, Mistral) and sizes (1B–70B parameters) on two creativity benchmarks (NeoCoder and CS4), focusing on measures of divergent creativity.
AI.result: CoVe tends to boost divergent thinking, DoLa dampens it, and RAG has little to no systematic impact on divergent creativity across the tested models and scales.
AI.conclusion: Different hallucination-reduction strategies have qualitatively different trade-offs with creativity; for scientific applications that need both accuracy and exploratory hypothesis generation, CoVe may be preferable, DoLa may be risky for creativity, and RAG is largely neutral, so method choice should be task- and creativity-aware.

title: CLINIC: Evaluating Multilingual Trustworthiness in Language Models for Healthcare
summary: Integrating language models (LMs) in healthcare systems holds great promise for improving medical workflows and decision-making. However, a critical barrier to their real-world adoption is the lack of reliable evaluation of their trustworthiness, especially in multilingual healthcare settings. Existing LMs are predominantly trained in high-resource languages, making them ill-equipped to handle the complexity and diversity of healthcare queries in mid- and low-resource languages, posing significant challenges for deploying them in global healthcare contexts where linguistic diversity is key. In this work, we present CLINIC, a Comprehensive Multilingual Benchmark to evaluate the trustworthiness of language models in healthcare. CLINIC systematically benchmarks LMs across five key dimensions of trustworthiness: truthfulness, fairness, safety, robustness, and privacy, operationalized through 18 diverse tasks, spanning 15 languages (covering all the major continents), and encompassing a wide array of critical healthcare topics like disease conditions, preventive actions, diagnostic tests, treatments, surgeries, and medications. Our extensive evaluation reveals that LMs struggle with factual correctness, demonstrate bias across demographic and linguistic groups, and are susceptible to privacy breaches and adversarial attacks. By highlighting these shortcomings, CLINIC lays the foundation for enhancing the global reach and safety of LMs in healthcare across diverse languages.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CLINIC, a multilingual benchmark to evaluate how trustworthy language models are in healthcare across many languages and trust dimensions.
AI.motivation: Language models could improve healthcare workflows and decision-making, but their real-world deployment is blocked by the lack of rigorous, realistic evaluation of trustworthiness, especially in multilingual contexts and for low- and mid-resource languages. Existing LMs are trained mainly on high-resource languages and may behave unreliably or unfairly when used globally in diverse linguistic settings.
AI.method: The authors construct CLINIC, a comprehensive multilingual benchmark suite. It defines five key dimensions of trustworthiness—truthfulness, fairness, safety, robustness, and privacy—and instantiates them into 18 different evaluation tasks. These tasks cover 15 languages from major world regions and many healthcare topics (diseases, prevention, diagnostics, treatments, surgeries, medications). They then systematically test language models on these tasks to quantify performance and failure modes along each dimension.
AI.result: Evaluation using CLINIC shows that current language models have substantial weaknesses: they frequently generate factually incorrect medical information, exhibit demographic and linguistic biases, and are vulnerable to both privacy leakage and adversarial manipulation across languages and tasks.
AI.conclusion: CLINIC exposes critical trust and safety gaps of current language models in multilingual healthcare scenarios and provides a standardized benchmark to measure and compare models. This resource is intended to guide future research and development toward safer, more accurate, fair, and robust multilingual LMs for global healthcare use.

title: Bounding Hallucinations: Information-Theoretic Guarantees for RAG Systems via Merlin-Arthur Protocols
summary: Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) models rely on retrieved evidence to guide large language model (LLM) generators, yet current systems treat retrieval as a weak heuristic rather than verifiable evidence. As a result, LLMs answer without support, hallucinate under incomplete or misleading context, and rely on spurious evidence. We introduce a training framework that treats the entire RAG pipeline -- both the retriever and the generator -- as an interactive proof system via an adaptation of the Merlin-Arthur (M/A) protocol. Arthur (the generator LLM) trains on questions of unkown provenance: Merlin provides helpful evidence, while Morgana injects adversarial, misleading context. Both use a linear-time XAI method to identify and modify the evidence most influential to Arthur. Consequently, Arthur learns to (i) answer when the context support the answer, (ii) reject when evidence is insufficient, and (iii) rely on the specific context spans that truly ground the answer. We further introduce a rigorous evaluation framework to disentangle explanation fidelity from baseline predictive errors. This allows us to introduce and measure the Explained Information Fraction (EIF), which normalizes M/A certified mutual-information guarantees relative to model capacity and imperfect benchmarks. Across three RAG datasets and two model families of varying sizes, M/A-trained LLMs show improved groundedness, completeness, soundness, and reject behavior, as well as reduced hallucinations -- without needing manually annotated unanswerable questions. The retriever likewise improves recall and MRR through automatically generated M/A hard positives and negatives. Our results demonstrate that autonomous interactive-proof-style supervision provides a principled and practical path toward reliable RAG systems that treat retrieved documents not as suggestions, but as verifiable evidence.

AI.tldr: They propose a new training framework that makes the whole RAG pipeline behave like an interactive proof system so LLMs only answer when supported by retrieved evidence and learn to reject or ignore misleading context.
AI.motivation: Current RAG systems treat retrieved documents as loose hints; LLMs often hallucinate, answer without sufficient support, or latch onto spurious evidence, and evaluation of faithfulness is confounded by model prediction errors.
AI.method: They adapt the Merlin-Arthur (M/A) interactive proof protocol to RAG: the generator LLM (Arthur) is trained with two retrieval agents—Merlin, which supplies helpful evidence, and Morgana, which injects adversarial misleading context. Both use a linear-time XAI method to identify the most influential evidence spans and modify them. Training encourages Arthur to (1) answer only when context supports the answer, (2) abstain when evidence is insufficient, and (3) base predictions on the specific supporting spans. They also design an evaluation framework separating explanation fidelity from base prediction errors and define Explained Information Fraction (EIF) based on M/A-certified mutual information, normalized by model capacity and benchmark noise.
AI.result: On three RAG datasets and two LLM families, models trained with the M/A framework show better groundedness, completeness, soundness, and rejection behavior, with fewer hallucinations, all without needing labels for unanswerable questions. The retriever also gains higher recall and MRR using automatically generated hard positives and negatives from the M/A process.
AI.conclusion: Training RAG systems as autonomous interactive-proof-style pipelines, where retrieved evidence is treated as verifiable proof rather than a suggestion, yields more reliable, faithful, and effective RAG models, improving both generator and retriever in a principled, annotation-efficient way.

title: Automating Historical Insight Extraction from Large-Scale Newspaper Archives via Neural Topic Modeling
comment: This is a preprint of a manuscript submitted to Digital Scholarship in the Humanities (Oxford University Press). The paper is currently under peer review
summary: Extracting coherent and human-understandable themes from large collections of unstructured historical newspaper archives presents significant challenges due to topic evolution, Optical Character Recognition (OCR) noise, and the sheer volume of text. Traditional topic-modeling methods, such as Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), often fall short in capturing the complexity and dynamic nature of discourse in historical texts. To address these limitations, we employ BERTopic. This neural topic-modeling approach leverages transformerbased embeddings to extract and classify topics, which, despite its growing popularity, still remains underused in historical research. Our study focuses on articles published between 1955 and 2018, specifically examining discourse on nuclear power and nuclear safety. We analyze various topic distributions across the corpus and trace their temporal evolution to uncover long-term trends and shifts in public discourse. This enables us to more accurately explore patterns in public discourse, including the co-occurrence of themes related to nuclear power and nuclear weapons and their shifts in topic importance over time. Our study demonstrates the scalability and contextual sensitivity of BERTopic as an alternative to traditional approaches, offering richer insights into historical discourses extracted from newspaper archives. These findings contribute to historical, nuclear, and social-science research while reflecting on current limitations and proposing potential directions for future work.

AI.tldr: The paper uses BERTopic, a transformer-based neural topic model, to analyze how newspaper discourse about nuclear power and safety evolved from 1955 to 2018, showing that it captures nuanced, time-varying themes better than traditional methods like LDA.
AI.motivation: Historical newspaper archives are massive, noisy (e.g., OCR errors), and contain evolving topics over time, making it hard to extract clear, human-interpretable themes. Traditional topic models like LDA struggle with dynamic discourse and contextual nuance, especially in long time spans and noisy text. The authors want a more scalable, context-sensitive method to study how public discourse around nuclear power and safety changes over decades.
AI.method: They apply BERTopic, which combines transformer-based text embeddings with clustering and topic representation techniques, to a corpus of newspaper articles from 1955–2018 about nuclear power and nuclear safety. They compute topic distributions, track how topics change in prevalence over time, and examine co-occurrences between themes such as nuclear power and nuclear weapons.
AI.result: BERTopic successfully identifies coherent topics and their temporal evolution in the nuclear-power discourse, including how themes about nuclear power, nuclear safety, and nuclear weapons co-occur and change in importance over time. It scales to a large archive and remains sensitive to contextual nuances that traditional models would likely miss.
AI.conclusion: BERTopic is a scalable and context-aware alternative to classical topic models for historical newspaper analysis, yielding richer insights into long-term shifts in public discourse on nuclear issues. The study underscores its value for historical, nuclear, and social-science research, and it points out current limitations and directions for improving topic modeling in historical corpora.

title: Building Patient Journeys in Hebrew: A Language Model for Clinical Timeline Extraction
comment: In Proceedings of the Workshop on Large Language Models and Generative AI for Health Informatics 2025, IJCAI 2025, Montreal, Canada
summary: We present a new Hebrew medical language model designed to extract structured clinical timelines from electronic health records, enabling the construction of patient journeys. Our model is based on DictaBERT 2.0 and continually pre-trained on over five million de-identified hospital records. To evaluate its effectiveness, we introduce two new datasets -- one from internal medicine and emergency departments, and another from oncology -- annotated for event temporal relations. Our results show that our model achieves strong performance on both datasets. We also find that vocabulary adaptation improves token efficiency and that de-identification does not compromise downstream performance, supporting privacy-conscious model development. The model is made available for research use under ethical restrictions.

AI.tldr: They build a Hebrew medical language model, pre-trained on de-identified hospital records, to automatically extract temporal clinical events and patient journeys, release new evaluation datasets, and show strong performance without sacrificing privacy.
AI.motivation: Electronic health records in Hebrew lack specialized language models and resources for extracting structured clinical timelines. There is a need to support downstream clinical and research tasks such as constructing patient journeys, while ensuring privacy via de-identification and assessing whether this de-identification harms model performance.
AI.method: They start from DictaBERT 2.0, a Hebrew language model, and continue pre-training it on over five million de-identified hospital records. They adapt the model’s vocabulary for medical text to improve tokenization efficiency. They create and annotate two datasets (internal medicine & emergency, and oncology) for temporal event relations between clinical events, and then evaluate the model on these tasks against relevant baselines.
AI.result: The new Hebrew medical model achieves strong performance in extracting temporal relations and building clinical timelines in both internal medicine/emergency and oncology datasets. Vocabulary adaptation improves token utilization. Experiments indicate that de-identification of records does not degrade downstream temporal relation extraction performance compared with non-de-identified data.
AI.conclusion: A domain-adapted Hebrew medical language model can effectively support automatic construction of structured clinical timelines from de-identified electronic health records. Medical-specific vocabulary and continued pre-training are beneficial, and privacy-preserving de-identification can be done without significant loss in performance. The model and datasets are released for research under ethical restrictions to foster further work on Hebrew clinical NLP.

title: Visualizing token importance for black-box language models
summary: We consider the problem of auditing black-box large language models (LLMs) to ensure they behave reliably when deployed in production settings, particularly in high-stakes domains such as legal, medical, and regulatory compliance. Existing approaches for LLM auditing often focus on isolated aspects of model behavior, such as detecting specific biases or evaluating fairness. We are interested in a more general question -- can we understand how the outputs of black-box LLMs depend on each input token? There is a critical need to have such tools in real-world applications that rely on inaccessible API endpoints to language models. However, this is a highly non-trivial problem, as LLMs are stochastic functions (i.e. two outputs will be different by chance), while computing prompt-level gradients to approximate input sensitivity is infeasible. To address this, we propose Distribution-Based Sensitivity Analysis (DBSA), a lightweight model-agnostic procedure to evaluate the sensitivity of the output of a language model for each input token, without making any distributional assumptions about the LLM. DBSA is developed as a practical tool for practitioners, enabling quick, plug-and-play visual exploration of LLMs reliance on specific input tokens. Through illustrative examples, we demonstrate how DBSA can enable users to inspect LLM inputs and find sensitivities that may be overlooked by existing LLM interpretability methods.

AI.tldr: They propose a lightweight, model-agnostic method (DBSA) to quantify how sensitive a black-box LLM’s output distribution is to each input token, enabling practical auditing and interpretability for high-stakes applications.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM auditing tools mostly test narrow properties (e.g., bias, fairness) and often assume access to model internals. In high-stakes settings using closed APIs, practitioners need a general, practical way to see how each input token influences model behavior, despite stochastic outputs and the infeasibility of gradient-based methods.
AI.method: They introduce Distribution-Based Sensitivity Analysis (DBSA), a black-box, model-agnostic procedure that perturbs or analyzes tokens and measures changes in the LLM’s output distribution. It does not rely on gradients or specific distributional assumptions and is designed to be lightweight and plug-and-play, with visualizations showing per-token sensitivity.
AI.result: Illustrative experiments show that DBSA can reveal which input tokens LLMs rely on, surfacing sensitivities and dependencies that other interpretability tools might miss, and supporting interactive visual exploration for auditors and practitioners.
AI.conclusion: DBSA provides a practical, general-purpose tool for auditing black-box LLMs by quantifying per-token sensitivity of outputs, addressing limitations of prior methods that focus on narrow behaviors or require model access, and helping practitioners better understand and monitor LLM behavior in real-world, high-stakes deployments.

title: Speculative Decoding Speed-of-Light: Optimal Lower Bounds via Branching Random Walks
summary: Speculative generation has emerged as a promising technique to accelerate inference in large language models (LLMs) by leveraging parallelism to verify multiple draft tokens simultaneously. However, the fundamental limits on the achievable speedup remain poorly understood. In this work, we establish the first ``tight'' lower bounds on the runtime of any deterministic speculative generation algorithm. This is achieved by drawing a parallel between the token generation process and branching random walks, which allows us to analyze the optimal draft tree selection problem. We prove, under basic assumptions, that the expected number of tokens successfully predicted per speculative iteration is bounded as $\mathbb{E}[X] \leq (μ+ μ_{(2)})\log(P )/μ^2 + O(1)$, where $P$ is the verifier's capacity, $μ$ is the expected entropy of the verifier's output distribution, and $μ_{(2)}$ is the expected second log-moment. This result provides new insights into the limits of parallel token generation, and could guide the design of future speculative decoding systems. Empirical evaluations on Llama models validate our theoretical predictions, confirming the tightness of our bounds in practical settings.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes fundamental performance limits of speculative generation for LLMs and provides tight lower bounds on achievable speedup by modeling token generation as a branching random walk.
AI.motivation: Speculative generation speeds up LLM inference by verifying multiple drafted tokens in parallel, but it is unclear how much speedup is theoretically possible. Existing work lacks tight lower bounds that characterize the best achievable performance regardless of algorithmic design. This paper aims to fill that gap and provide guidance for future speculative decoding designs.
AI.method: The authors model the token generation process as a branching random walk and formalize the optimal draft tree selection problem. Under basic assumptions on the verifier’s output distribution, they derive tight lower bounds on the expected number of correctly predicted tokens per speculative iteration. Their key bound involves the verifier capacity P, the expected entropy μ of the verifier’s distribution, and the expected second log-moment μ_(2). They supplement the theory with empirical tests on Llama models.
AI.result: They prove that for any deterministic speculative generation algorithm, the expected number of successfully predicted tokens per speculative iteration satisfies E[X] ≤ (μ + μ_(2))·log(P)/μ^2 + O(1). This bound is shown to be tight, meaning that no deterministic algorithm can asymptotically beat it under the stated assumptions. Experiments with Llama-based models demonstrate that observed behavior matches the theoretical predictions, validating the tightness and practical relevance of the bound.
AI.conclusion: There is a fundamental, quantifiable limit to the speedup achievable by deterministic speculative generation, scaling at most logarithmically with the verifier’s capacity and controlled by entropy-related properties of the verifier distribution. Viewing token generation as a branching random walk yields tight lower bounds that align with empirical behavior on real LLMs, offering a principled basis for designing and evaluating future speculative decoding systems.

title: SUMFORU: An LLM-Based Review Summarization Framework for Personalized Purchase Decision Support
summary: Online product reviews contain rich but noisy signals that overwhelm users and hinder effective decision-making. Existing LLM-based summarizers remain generic and fail to account for individual preferences, limiting their practical utility. We propose SUMFORU, a steerable review summarization framework that aligns outputs with explicit user personas to support personalized purchase decisions. Our approach integrates a high-quality data pipeline built from the Amazon 2023 Review Dataset with a two-stage alignment procedure: (1) persona-aware Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) via asymmetric knowledge distillation, and (2) Reinforcement Learning with AI Feedback (RLAIF) using a preference estimator to capture fine-grained, persona-relevant signals. We evaluate the model across rule-based, LLM-based, and human-centered metrics, demonstrating consistent improvements in consistency, grounding, and preference alignment. Our framework achieves the highest performance across all evaluation settings and generalizes effectively to unseen product categories. Our results highlight the promise of steerable pluralistic alignment for building next-generation personalized decision-support systems.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SUMFORU, a framework for personalized, persona-aware summarization of online product reviews using LLMs.
AI.motivation: Online reviews are rich but noisy, overwhelming users and making it hard to reach decisions. Existing LLM summarizers are generic, ignore individual preferences, and thus are of limited practical use for personalized purchase decisions.
AI.method: The authors build a pipeline on top of the Amazon 2023 Review Dataset and design SUMFORU with two key stages: (1) persona-aware supervised fine-tuning using asymmetric knowledge distillation, where a stronger model teaches a smaller one to generate summaries tailored to explicit user personas; and (2) reinforcement learning with AI feedback (RLAIF), where a preference estimator model provides fine-grained, persona-relevant feedback to further align the summarizer with user-specific needs. They then evaluate on multiple metric families: rule-based metrics, LLM-judged metrics, and human evaluations.
AI.result: SUMFORU improves on consistency, factual grounding, and alignment with specified user personas compared with baseline LLM summarizers. It achieves the best performance across all evaluation settings and shows good generalization to product categories not seen during training.
AI.conclusion: Steerable, persona-aware alignment via SFT plus RLAIF can produce more useful, personalized review summaries that better support purchase decisions. The work suggests that pluralistic, preference-conditioned alignment is a promising direction for next-generation personalized decision-support systems.
